SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1a2.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def example_keyword(count: int, case_insensitive: bool = True): if case_insensitive: # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Registering Custom Date Converter (Python) DESCRIPTION: This Python code defines a custom argument converter function `parse_fi_date` that parses dates in the Finnish format (dd.mm.yyyy) and registers it with Robot Framework using the `ROBOT_LIBRARY_CONVERTERS` dictionary. It also shows a keyword using the custom converter. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc1.rst#_snippet_26 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from datetime import date # Converter function. def parse_fi_date(value): day, month, year = value.split('.') return date(int(year), int(month), int(day)) # Register converter function for the specified type. ROBOT_LIBRARY_CONVERTERS = {date: parse_fi_date} # Keyword using custom converter. Converter is got based on argument type. def keyword(arg: date): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Usage of Keyword with Embedded Arguments DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to use a keyword defined with embedded arguments in Robot Framework. Demonstrates the possibility to use both positional and named arguments to specify parameters for the function. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc1.rst#_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Number of horses should be 2 Number of horses should be count=2 Number of dogs should be 3 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example Resource File Structure in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates a complete resource file including settings, variables and keywords. It showcases documentation, library imports, variable definitions, and keyword implementation using Robot Framework syntax. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/ResourceAndVariableFiles.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Documentation An example resource file Library SeleniumLibrary Resource ${RESOURCES}/common.resource *** Variables *** ${HOST} localhost:7272 ${LOGIN URL} http://${HOST}/ ${WELCOME URL} http://${HOST}/welcome.html ${BROWSER} Firefox *** Keywords *** Open Login Page [Documentation] Opens browser to login page Open Browser ${LOGIN URL} ${BROWSER} Title Should Be Login Page Input Name [Arguments] ${name} Input Text username_field ${name} Input Password [Arguments] ${password} Input Text password_field ${password} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Date Converter with Validation DESCRIPTION: This python snippet enhances the previous date converter by adding input validation using regular expressions. It ensures that the input string matches the expected `dd.mm.yyyy` format and raises a `ValueError` with a user-friendly message if the format is invalid. This improves error reporting and debugging. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_60 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from datetime import date import re def parse_fi_date(value): # Validate input using regular expression and raise ValueError if not valid. match = re.match(r'(\d{1,2})\.(\d{1,2})\.(\d{4})$', value) if not match: raise ValueError(f"Expected date in format 'dd.mm.yyyy', got '{value}'.") day, month, year = match.groups() return date(int(year), int(month), int(day)) ROBOT_LIBRARY_CONVERTERS = {date: parse_fi_date} def keyword(arg: date): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using named-only arguments in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework test case demonstrates how to call a Python keyword that uses named-only arguments. The `case_sensitive` argument must be passed as a keyword argument. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Sort Words Foo bar baZ Sort Words Foo bar baZ case_sensitive=True ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: IF/ELSE example in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates the new native IF/ELSE syntax in Robot Framework 4.0. It shows a simple conditional statement where a keyword is executed if the variable ${x} is greater than 0. It also shows the equivalent using Run Keyword If. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0a3.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` IF ${x} > 0 Some positive keyword END Run Keyword If ${x} > 0 Some positive keyword ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: JSON Variable File Example DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows an example of a JSON file used as a variable file in Robot Framework. It defines a string, an integer, a list, and a dictionary, which are then used as Robot Framework variables. JSON files are automatically recognized by the `.json` extension and do not require extra modules to be installed in newer Robot Framework versions. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/ResourceAndVariableFiles.rst#_snippet_21 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "string": "Hello, world!", "integer": 42, "list": [ "one", "two" ], "dict": { "one": "yksi", "two": "kaksi", "with spaces": "kolme" } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Logging to Console and Log File using robot.api.logger Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use the `robot.api.logger` to log messages to both the console and the log file. It uses the `logger.console` method to write only to the console and `logger.info` with `also_console=True` to write to both. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_85 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api import logger def log_to_console(arg): logger.console('Message only to console.') def log_to_console_and_log_file(arg): logger.info('Message both to log and to console.', also_console=True) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Keywords with Embedded Arguments in Python DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to create Robot Framework keywords that accept embedded arguments using the `@keyword` decorator from `robot.api.deco`. It shows how to define a custom name for the keyword and how the embedded arguments are passed to the function. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_69 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api.deco import keyword @keyword('Select ${animal} from list') def select_animal_from_list(animal): ... @keyword('Number of ${animals} should be') def number_of_animals_should_be(animals, count): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Conditional Variable Creation in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to conditionally create variables using IF/ELSE structures within Robot Framework test cases. This allows for dynamic variable assignment based on runtime conditions. No specific dependencies are required other than the Robot Framework itself. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Long value VAR ${long} ... This value is rather long. ... It has been split to multiple lines. ... Parts will be joined together with a space. Multiline VAR ${multiline} ... First line. ... Second line. ... Last line. ... separator=\n List # Creates a list with three items. VAR @{list} a b c Dictionary # Creates a dictionary with two items. VAR &{dict} key=value second=item Normal IF IF 1 > 0 VAR ${x} true value ELSE VAR ${x} false value END Inline IF IF 1 > 0 VAR ${x} true value ELSE VAR ${x} false value ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example Python Keyword with Mixed Arguments DESCRIPTION: Illustrates a Python keyword that accepts both embedded and normal arguments. The 'animals' argument is embedded in the keyword name, while 'count' is passed as a normal argument. This example requires the Robot Framework 'keyword' decorator from the robot.api.deco module. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @keyword('Number of ${animals} should be') def example(animals, count): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: IF/ELSE Example in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework test case demonstrates the usage of IF and ELSE statements. It checks if the variable `${rc}` is greater than zero. If it is, `Some keyword` is executed; otherwise, `Another keyword` is executed. Note that `${rc}` is used in the `$rc` format, meaning the variable's value, not its string representation, is used. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example IF $rc > 0 Some keyword ELSE Another keyword END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using STRICT Mode in FOR IN ZIP Loops DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the `STRICT` mode for `FOR IN ZIP` loops, which enforces that all lists must have equal lengths. If the lists have different lengths, the loop will fail. It also defines lists of characters and numbers for demonstration. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1rc1.rst#_snippet_21 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Variables *** @{CHARACTERS} a b c d f @{NUMBERS} 1 2 3 *** Test Cases *** STRICT mode [Documentation] This loop fails due to lists lengths being different. FOR ${c} ${n} IN ZIP ${CHARACTERS} ${NUMBERS} mode=STRICT Log ${c}: ${n} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example Python Keyword using Literal Type Hint DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to use the `Literal` type hint in a Python keyword argument. This restricts the allowed values for the argument to a specific set. The keyword requires the `Literal` type from the `typing` module and the `@keyword` decorator from `robot.api.deco`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def example(arg: Literal['x', 'y', 'z']): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Enhanced For Loop Syntax Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the enhanced FOR loop syntax introduced in Robot Framework 3.1, providing a cleaner and more readable way to define loops. The new syntax uses `FOR` to start the loop, does not require escaping keywords within the loop, and ends with an explicit `END` statement. This snippet showcases the recommended syntax for defining loops in modern Robot Framework tests. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2a1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` FOR ${animal} IN cat dog cow Keyword ${animal} Another keyword END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: WHILE Loop with 'limit' and 'on_limit' in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework example demonstrates the use of the `limit` and `on_limit` options in a `WHILE` loop. The loop runs a maximum of 10 times. If the limit is reached, the `on_limit=PASS` option causes the loop to exit without failing the test case. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1rc1.rst#_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** WHILE with 'limit' and 'on_limit' WHILE True limit=10 on_limit=PASS Log to console Hello! END Log to console Hello once more! ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Strip Spaces Keyword with Keyword-Only Arguments DESCRIPTION: This Python code defines a keyword `strip_spaces` that accepts a `word` argument and two keyword-only arguments (`left` and `right`). It strips leading and/or trailing spaces from the word based on the values of the `left` and `right` arguments. Both arguments are optional with default values of True. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_33 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def strip_spaces(word, *, left=True, right=True): if left: word = word.lstrip() if right: word = word.rstrip() return word ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: New For Loop Example with Pipe Separated Format DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates the new FOR loop syntax within the pipe-separated format, which is the recommended way to define loops in Robot Framework 3.2. It uses `FOR` instead of `:FOR` and includes an explicit `END` marker to define the loop's boundaries. The spaces are part of the pipe-separated format. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2b2.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` | FOR | ${x} | IN | 1 | 2 | | Log | ${x} | END | ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Listener API v3 Example (Keyword and WHILE Loop) DESCRIPTION: This Python code demonstrates how to use the enhanced listener API version 3 to get notifications about started keywords and ended WHILE loops during Robot Framework execution. It requires the 'robot' library and defines 'start_keyword' and 'end_while' methods that print information about these events to standard output. This listener must be enabled during the Robot Framework test execution to observe the output. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot import result, running def start_keyword(data: running.Keyword, result: result.Keyword): print(f"Keyword '{result.full_name}' used on line {data.lineno} started.") def end_while(data: running.While, result: result.While): print(f"WHILE loop on line {data.lineno} ended with status {result.status} " f"after {len(result.body)} iterations.") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Inline Conditional Variable Assignment DESCRIPTION: Shows an example of an inline IF/ELSE structure used for assigning a value to a variable conditionally. This is a more concise way to express the same logic as the standard IF/ELSE. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc1.rst#_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` Inline IF IF 1 > 0 VAR ${x} true value ELSE VAR ${x} false value ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Library Documentation Format (Python) DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to set the documentation format of a Robot Framework library using the `ROBOT_LIBRARY_DOC_FORMAT` attribute. The value is set to 'reST', indicating reStructuredText. This attribute should be a module-level attribute. The `keyword` function serves as a placeholder for actual keyword implementation. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` """A library for *documentation format* demonstration purposes. This documentation is created using reStructuredText__. Here is a link to the only `Keyword`. __ http://docutils.sourceforge.net """ ROBOT_LIBRARY_DOC_FORMAT = 'reST' def keyword(): """**Nothing** to see here. Not even in the table below. ======= ===== ===== Table here has nothing to see. ======= ===== ===== """ pass ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Merging Suites Executed in Pieces DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates merging test suite results when the suite is executed in pieces using `--include` and `--exclude` options. The example runs smoke tests, then runs the remaining tests, and finally merges the results using `--merge`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/PostProcessing.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` robot --include smoke --output smoke.xml tests # first run some tests robot --exclude smoke --output others.xml tests # then run others rebot --merge smoke.xml others.xml # finally merge results ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Date Conversion with Input Validation DESCRIPTION: This Python code improves the `parse_fi_date` function by adding input validation using regular expressions. If the input string does not match the expected `dd.mm.yyyy` format, a `ValueError` is raised with a descriptive error message. The converter function is then registered for the `date` type. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc2.rst#_snippet_21 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from datetime import date import re def parse_fi_date(value): # Validate input using regular expression and raise ValueError if not valid. match = re.match(r'(\d{1,2})\.(\d{1,2})\.(\d{4})$', value) if not match: raise ValueError(f"Expected date in format 'dd.mm.yyyy', got '{value}'.") day, month, year = match.groups() return date(int(year), int(month), int(day)) ROBOT_LIBRARY_CONVERTERS = {date: parse_fi_date} def keyword(arg: date): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Test Cases: Argument Handling DESCRIPTION: These test cases demonstrate how Robot Framework handles different types of arguments (positional, named, and free named) when using dynamic libraries. It shows how the arguments are passed to the `run_keyword` method as `args` and `kwargs`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_101 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** # args, kwargs No arguments Dynamic # [], {} Only positional Dynamic x # [x], {} Dynamic x y # [x, y], {} Only free named Dynamic x=1 # [], {x: 1} Dynamic x=1 y=2 z=3 # [], {x: 1, y: 2, z: 3} Positional and free named Dynamic x y=2 # [x], {y: 2} Dynamic x y=2 z=3 # [x], {y: 2, z: 3} Positional as named and free named Dynamic a=1 x=1 # [], {a: 1, x: 1} Dynamic b=2 x=1 a=1 # [], {a: 1, b: 2, x: 1} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework with pip DESCRIPTION: These commands demonstrate how to install or upgrade Robot Framework to the latest pre-release version, or a specific release candidate version, using pip. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1rc1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==3.1rc1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Importing Same Library Multiple Times with Custom Names DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates importing the same library multiple times with different arguments by using the AS keyword to assign distinct names to each instance. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/UsingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Library SomeLibrary localhost 1234 AS LocalLib Library SomeLibrary server.domain 8080 AS RemoteLib *** Test Cases *** Example LocalLib.Some Keyword some arg second arg RemoteLib.Some Keyword another arg whatever LocalLib.Another Keyword ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Adding Groups Programmatically in Python DESCRIPTION: This Python code demonstrates how to add a group with keywords to a test case programmatically using Robot Framework's API. A `SuiteVisitor` is used to traverse the test suite, and the `create_group` and `create_keyword` methods add the group and its keywords to each test. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.2b1.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api import SuiteVisitor class GroupAdder(SuiteVisitor): def start_test(self, test): group = test.body.create_group(name='Example') group.body.create_keyword(name='Log', args=['Hello, world!']) group.body.create_keyword(name='No Operation') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Suite Documentation in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework snippet demonstrates how to set suite-level documentation using the `Documentation` setting in the `Settings` section. The documentation can be formatted using Robot Framework's formatting syntax and split across multiple lines. This documentation will appear in reports and logs. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/CreatingTestSuites.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Documentation An example suite documentation with *some* _formatting_. ... Long documentation can be split into multiple lines. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Glob Patterns to Match Errors in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to use glob patterns to match error messages. The `type=GLOB` parameter specifies that the messages should be treated as glob patterns. `${pattern}` must be defined as a variable. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc1.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Glob pattern TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT ValueError: * type=GLOB Error Handler 1 EXCEPT [Ee]rror ?? occurred ${pattern} type=glob Error Handler 2 END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Install Latest Robot Framework Pre-release with Pip (Python) DESCRIPTION: This command installs the latest pre-release version of Robot Framework using pip, the Python package installer. The `--pre` flag allows installation of pre-release versions, and `--upgrade` ensures the existing Robot Framework installation is updated. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.1a2.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Capturing error message in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This code shows how to capture the error message into a variable using the AS keyword in an EXCEPT branch. This allows the error message to be used in the error handler. The first example uses a GLOB pattern and captures the error message, while the second example captures any error message. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Capture error TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT ValueError: * type=GLOB AS ${error} Error Handler 1 ${error} EXCEPT AS ${error} Error Handler 2 ${error} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Automatic argument conversion from default values DESCRIPTION: This Python example demonstrates how Robot Framework infers argument types from default values when no explicit type is specified. The `count` argument will be treated as an integer because of the default value `-1`, and `case_insensitive` will be treated as a boolean. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def example_keyword(count=-1, case_insensitive=True): if case_insensitive: # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: ELSE branch in Robot Framework TRY/EXCEPT DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates the usage of the ELSE branch in a TRY/EXCEPT block. The ELSE branch is executed only if no error occurs in the TRY block. It must be placed after the EXCEPT blocks. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0a1.rst#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** ELSE branch TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT X Log Error 'X' occurred! EXCEPT Y Log Error 'Y' occurred! ELSE Log No error occurred! END Keyword Outside ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Module with Arguments for Variable Files DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates a Python module that takes arguments to dynamically determine the variables to be returned. The `get_variables` function accepts an argument and returns different sets of variables based on its value. This allows for conditional variable loading in Robot Framework. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/ResourceAndVariableFiles.rst#_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` variables1 = {'scalar': 'Scalar variable', 'LIST__list': ['List','variable']} variables2 = {'scalar' : 'Some other value', 'LIST__list': ['Some','other','value'], 'extra': 'variables1 does not have this at all'} def get_variables(arg): if arg == 'one': return variables1 else: return variables2 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Conditional Execution with IF/ELSE Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates the use of IF/ELSE blocks in Robot Framework to conditionally execute keywords based on a variable's value. It checks if `${rc}` is greater than zero and executes `Some keyword` if true, otherwise executes `Another keyword`. This provides a simple way to implement branching logic within a test case. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b3.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example IF ${rc} > 0 Some keyword ELSE Another keyword END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Literal Type Hinting DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the use of Python's `Literal` type hint to restrict argument values. Robot Framework validates arguments against the specified literal values and performs conversion where possible. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc2.rst#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def example(arg: Literal['x', 'y', 'z']): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Nested FOR and IF Loops in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example showcases nested FOR and IF loops in Robot Framework. The outer loop iterates through rows, and the inner loop iterates through cells within each row. An IF condition checks if a cell's value is not equal to 'IGNORE', and if true, it processes the cell using `Process Cell` keyword. This demonstrates how to implement complex iterative and conditional logic. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b3.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` FOR ${row} IN @{rows} FOR ${cell} IN @{row} IF "${cell}" != "IGNORE" Process Cell ${cell} END END END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Keyword Tags with @keyword Decorator DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to set tags for a Robot Framework keyword using the `@keyword` decorator. The `login` and `another_example` functions are decorated with `@keyword(tags=['tag1', 'tag2'])` and `@keyword('Custom name', ['tags', 'here'])` respectively, assigning the specified tags to these keywords. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_22 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api.deco import keyword @keyword(tags=['tag1', 'tag2']) def login(username, password): ... @keyword('Custom name', ['tags', 'here']) def another_example(): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Custom Keyword Name with @keyword Decorator DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to set a custom name for a Robot Framework keyword using the `@keyword` decorator with an argument. The `login` function is decorated with `@keyword('Login via user panel')`, achieving the same result as setting the `robot_name` attribute directly. This is a more concise and readable way to define custom keyword names. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_21 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api.deco import keyword @keyword('Login via user panel') def login(username, password): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework GROUP Syntax with Templates DESCRIPTION: This demonstrates how the `GROUP` syntax can be used to group iterations when utilizing test templates in Robot Framework. It showcases grouping different sets of data for a single templated test. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.2.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Library String Test Template Upper case should be *** Test Cases *** Template example GROUP ASCII characters a A z Z END GROUP Latin-1 characters SS END GROUP Numbers 1 1 9 9 END *** Keywords *** Upper case should be [Arguments] ${char} ${expected} ${actual} = Convert To Upper Case ${char} Should Be Equal ${actual} ${expected} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Conditional Execution with ELSE IF Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates the use of IF/ELSE IF/ELSE blocks in Robot Framework to conditionally execute keywords based on multiple conditions. It checks the value of `${rc}` and executes different keywords depending on whether it is positive, negative, zero, or something else. The special `$rc` format is used to use the variable value itself, not its string representation, when conditions are evaluated. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b3.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example IF $rc > 0 Positive keyword ELSE IF $rc < 0 Negative keyword ELSE IF $rc == 0 Zero keyword ELSE Fail Unexpected rc: ${rc} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Preprocessor Python DESCRIPTION: This Python snippet demonstrates how to create a custom preprocessor for Robot Framework data files. It replaces custom headers (e.g., `=== Test Cases ===`) with the standard Robot Framework headers (e.g., `*** Test Cases ***`) before parsing the data using `TestSuite.from_string`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from pathlib import Path from robot.running import TestDefaults, TestSuite class RobotPreprocessor: extension = '.robot' def parse(self, source: Path, defaults: TestDefaults) -> TestSuite: data = source.read_text() for header in 'Settings', 'Variables', 'Test Cases', 'Keywords': data = data.replace(f'=== {header} ===', f'*** {header} ***') suite = TestSuite.from_string(data, defaults=defaults) return suite.config(name=TestSuite.name_from_source(source), source=source) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Dictionary Iteration with FOR Loops in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to iterate dictionary items using FOR loops in Robot Framework when the values are `&{dict}` variables. Includes examples with multiple dictionaries and the `key=value` syntax. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` FOR ${key} ${value} IN &{dict} Log Key is '${key}' and value is '${value}'. END ``` LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` FOR ${key} ${value} IN &{first} &{second} one=more Log Key is '${key}' and value is '${value}'. END ``` LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` FOR ${item} IN &{dict} Length Should Be ${item} 2 Log Key is '${item}[0]' and value is '${item}[1]'. END ``` LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` FOR ${index} ${key} ${value} IN ENUMERATE &{dict} Log Key is '${key}' and value is '${value}' at index ${index}. END FOR ${item} IN ENUMERATE &{dict} Length Should Be ${item} 3 Log Key is '${item}[1]' and value is '${item}[2]' at index ${item}[0]. END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining User Keywords with Mixed Arguments in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to define user keywords that mix embedded arguments and normal arguments in Robot Framework. The `${animals}` argument is embedded within the keyword name, while `${count}` is a standard argument defined using `[Arguments]`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1b1.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Number of horses is 2 Number of dogs is 3 *** Keywords *** Number of ${animals} is [Arguments] ${count} Log to console There are ${count} ${animals}. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Explicit Exact Match in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to enforce an exact match for error messages using the 'type=literal' parameter. This is the default matching behavior, but it can be explicitly specified for clarity. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc2.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Explicit exact match TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT Error 13 occurred type=literal Error Handler 2 END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Type Hinting with Union (New Way) - Python DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows the new, more concise syntax for defining a union type for a function argument in Python 3.10 and Robot Framework 4.1.1 or newer, using the `|` operator. It does not require any imports. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.1.1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` def example(arg: int | float): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: User Keyword with Embedded and Normal Arguments DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to define a user keyword in Robot Framework that combines both embedded arguments (e.g., `${animals}`) and normal arguments (e.g., `${count}`). It demonstrates the new capability in Robot Framework 6.1 to mix these argument types in user keywords. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Number of horses is 2 Number of dogs is 3 *** Keywords *** Number of ${animals} is [Arguments] ${count} Log to console There are ${count} ${animals}. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Making Robot Files Executable DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to make a .robot file executable on UNIX-like systems by adding a shebang and execution permissions. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/BasicUsage.rst#_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` #!/usr/bin/env robot *** Test Cases *** Example Log to console Executing! ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Multiple messages with one EXCEPT in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to use multiple messages with a single EXCEPT branch. The EXCEPT branch is executed if any of the specified messages match the error message from the TRY block. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0a1.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Multiple messages with one EXCEPT TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT Error message Another error ${message} # Match any of these. Error handler END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Named-only arguments in User Keywords DESCRIPTION: These Robot Framework user keywords examples show how to use named-only arguments. The first example uses varargs and named arguments. The second example shows named arguments without varargs. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** With Varargs [Arguments] @{varargs} ${named} Log Many @{varargs} ${named} ``` LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` Without Varargs [Arguments] @{} ${first} ${second}=default Log Many ${first} ${second} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Custom Suite Name in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework snippet demonstrates how to set a custom name for a test suite using the `Name` setting in the `Settings` section. This overrides the default naming convention based on the file or directory name. The custom name will be used in reports and logs. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/CreatingTestSuites.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Name Custom suite name ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Keyword with Named-Only Arguments (Python 3) DESCRIPTION: This Python 3 code shows how to use keyword-only (named-only) arguments in Python libraries for Robot Framework. This allows you to enforce that certain arguments must be passed by name. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1rc1.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def sort_words(*words, case_sensitive=False): key = str.lower if case_sensitive else None return sorted(words, key=key) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Specific Robot Framework Version with pip DESCRIPTION: This command installs a specific version of Robot Framework (6.0.1) using the pip package installer. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.0.1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==6.0.1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Variables with Arguments in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to pass arguments to variable files in Robot Framework. The `Variables` setting is used to import a Python module (`example.py`) and pass arguments to its `get_variables` function. The first example converts '42' to an integer. The second example uses named argument syntax. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/ResourceAndVariableFiles.rst#_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Variables example.py 42 # Converted to integer. Variables example.py second=value # Named argument syntax. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Dictionary Variable Creation DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a dictionary variable in Robot Framework using the `&` prefix and assigning key-value pairs to it. This creates a dictionary with the specified items. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc1.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` Dictionary # Creates a dictionary with two items. VAR &{dict} key=value second=item ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: User keyword with named-only arguments (Without Varargs) DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework snippet showcases the usage of named-only arguments in user-defined keywords, excluding variable arguments. `${first}` is the first positional argument, and `${second}` is a named argument with a default value. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1b1.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** Without Varargs [Arguments] @{} ${first} ${second}=default Log Many ${first} ${second} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Stringified Type Hints in Python DESCRIPTION: Python code demonstrating the use of stringified type hints like `'list[int]'` and `'int | float'` for argument conversion. This is useful for compatibility with older Python versions. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0a1.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def example(a: 'list[int]', b: 'int | float'): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example Robot Framework Library Module DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates a simple Robot Framework library implemented as a Python module. It defines two functions, `hello` and `do_nothing`, which can be used as keywords in Robot Framework test cases. The `hello` function takes a name as input and prints a greeting. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def hello(name): print(f"Hello, {name}!") def do_nothing(): pass ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: New FOR Loop Syntax Example - Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates the new `FOR` loop syntax introduced in Robot Framework 3.1. This syntax is the current standard for writing loops in Robot Framework. The example iterates over a list of animals and executes keywords with each animal. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b3.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` FOR ${animal} IN cat dog cow Keyword ${animal} Another keyword END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Regular Expressions to Match Errors in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to use regular expressions to match error messages. The `type=regexp` parameter specifies that the messages should be treated as regular expressions. Because the backslash is an escape character, it needs to be escaped with another backslash when used in regular expressions. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc1.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Regular expression TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT ValueError: .* type=regexp Error Handler 1 EXCEPT [Ee]rror \\d+ occurred type=regexp # Backslash needs to be escaped. Error Handler 2 END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Merging Re-executed Tests DESCRIPTION: Shows how to re-execute failing tests and merge the results back into the original output. This example first executes all tests, then re-executes the failing tests using `--rerunfailed`, and finally merges the re-execution results into the original output using `--merge`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/PostProcessing.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` robot --output original.xml tests # first execute all tests robot --rerunfailed original.xml --output rerun.xml tests # then re-execute failing rebot --merge original.xml rerun.xml # finally merge results ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Importing Libraries Using Library Setting DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to import test libraries in the Settings section using the Library setting. The library name or path is case- and space-sensitive. Arguments can be passed to the library during import. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/UsingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Library OperatingSystem Library path/to/MyLibrary.py Library my.package.TestLibrary Library LibraryAcceptingArguments arg1 arg2 Library ${LIBRARY} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: BREAK and CONTINUE with FOR Loops DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the usage of BREAK and CONTINUE statements within a FOR loop in Robot Framework, often in combination with inline IF statements. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc2.rst#_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example FOR ${x} IN RANGE 1000 IF ${x} > 10 BREAK Log Executed only when ${x} < 11 IF ${x} % 2 == 0 CONTINUE Log Executed only when ${x} is odd. END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: RETURN Statement Examples Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: These examples demonstrate different uses of the `RETURN` statement: returning a value at the end of a keyword, returning conditionally based on a condition, and returning early to prevent further execution. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.rst#_snippet_20 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** Return at the end Some Keyword ${result} = Another Keyword RETURN ${result} Return conditionally IF ${condition} RETURN Something ELSE RETURN Something else END Early return IF ${not applicable} RETURN Some Keyword Another Keyword ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: TRY/EXCEPT/ELSE/FINALLY Block Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to use TRY, EXCEPT, ELSE and FINALLY blocks in a Robot Framework test case for exception handling. The TRY block executes code that may raise an exception. The EXCEPT block catches any exceptions that occur within the TRY block. The ELSE block is executed only if no exception occurred in the TRY block. The FINALLY block is always executed, regardless of whether an exception occurred or not. These blocks facilitate robust error handling and resource cleanup. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0a1.rst#_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** TRY/EXCEPT/ELSE/FINALLY TRY Some keyword EXCEPT Log Error occurred! ELSE Log No error occurred. FINALLY Log Always executed. END TRY/FINALLY Open Connection TRY Use Connection FINALLY Close Connection END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Skipping Tests with the robot:skip-on-failure Tag DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to use the `robot:skip-on-failure` tag to mark a test case as skipped if it fails. Instead of the test failing, it will be marked as skipped. This approach allows for granular control over which tests are automatically skipped on failure within the test suite itself. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/TestExecution.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example [Tags] robot:skip-on-failure Fail this test will be marked as skipped instead of failed ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Logging to Console - Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to log messages to both the log file and the console using the `CONSOLE` log level, available from Robot Framework 6.1 onwards. This is achieved by prefixing the log message with `*CONSOLE*`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_83 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def my_keyword(arg): ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Iterating with FOR IN ZIP in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to use the `FOR IN ZIP` loop to iterate over two lists simultaneously, logging the corresponding elements. It uses the previously defined animal lists (@{ANIMALS} and @{ELIMET}) to print each animal name in English and Finnish. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1rc1.rst#_snippet_19 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example FOR ${en} ${fi} IN ZIP ${ANIMALS} ${ELIMET} Log ${en} is ${fi} in Finnish END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Capturing Error Message into a Variable in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to capture the error message into a variable using `AS ${var}`. This is useful when using pattern matching or catching any error. The variable `${error}` will contain the error message. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc1.rst#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Capture error TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT ValueError: * type=GLOB AS ${error} Error Handler 1 ${error} EXCEPT AS ${error} Error Handler 2 ${error} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Registering Custom Converter in Robot Framework - Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet registers the `parse_fi_date` function as a custom converter for the `date` type in Robot Framework. This allows Robot Framework keywords to automatically convert string arguments in 'dd.mm.yyyy' format to `datetime.date` objects. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.rst#_snippet_24 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` ROBOT_LIBRARY_CONVERTERS = {date: parse_fi_date} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Nested FOR and IF Structures in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to nest FOR loops and IF statements in Robot Framework. It iterates through a list of rows and then through cells in each row. If a cell's value is not 'IGNORE', the `Process Cell` keyword is executed with the cell's value. This demonstrates the ability to create complex control flow logic by nesting structures. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b2.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` FOR ${row} IN @{rows} FOR ${cell} IN @{row} IF "${cell}" != "IGNORE" Process Cell ${cell} END END END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Removing Tags Using Negative Syntax DESCRIPTION: Shows how to remove a tag that has been globally set using the `-tag` syntax within a test case's `[Tags]` setting. This allows for selectively removing tags from individual tests. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc1.rst#_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Test Tags all most *** Test Cases *** T1 No Operation T2 [Tags] one -most No Operation T3 No Operation ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Dictionary Variable Definition - Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Defines a dictionary variable in Robot Framework using the new `&{DICT}` syntax. This example shows how to assign key-value pairs to a dictionary variable within the variable table. It creates a dictionary with string and numerical values. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-2.9.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Variables *** &{DICT} key=value second=2 third=${3} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Install Robot Framework 3.1 beta 1 (specific version) DESCRIPTION: This command installs the specified version of Robot Framework using pip. This ensures that a consistent version of robot framework will be used. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1b1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==3.1b1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Basic TRY/EXCEPT block in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows a basic TRY/EXCEPT block in Robot Framework. If 'Some Keyword' passes, the EXCEPT block is skipped. If it fails with the message 'Error message', the 'Error Handler Keyword' is executed. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** First example TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT Error message Error Handler Keyword END Keyword Outside ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Reading Arguments from Standard Input DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to read arguments from the standard input stream using the special argument file name `STDIN`. This is useful when generating arguments with a script. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/BasicUsage.rst#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` generate_arguments.sh | robot --argumentfile STDIN generate_arguments.sh | robot --name Example --argumentfile STDIN tests.robot ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Match start of error message in Robot Framework EXCEPT DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to use the STARTS: prefix to match the beginning of error messages in EXCEPT branches. Only the beginning of the error message needs to match. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0a1.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Match start TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT STARTS: ValueError: STARTS: ${beginning} Error Handler END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Combining --suite and --test options DESCRIPTION: This illustrates how to combine the `--suite` and `--test` options to select specific tests within specific suites. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/ConfiguringExecution.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` --suite mysuite --test mytest # Match test 'mytest' if its inside suite 'mysuite'. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Install Robot Framework with pip DESCRIPTION: This command upgrades Robot Framework to the latest available version using pip, the Python package installer. It assumes pip is already installed on the system. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2.1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` pip install --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Basic IF Statement in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates the basic IF statement in Robot Framework. If the condition `${rc} > 0` is true, the keywords `Some keyword` and `Another keyword` will be executed. The `IF` and `END` markers define the conditional block. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0rc1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example IF ${rc} > 0 Some keyword Another keyword END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Custom Types and Converters for Different Date Formats - Python DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to create custom date types (FiDate and UsDate) and corresponding converters to handle different date formats. It also shows how to register these converters using the `@library` decorator and use them in Robot Framework keywords. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.rst#_snippet_28 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from datetime import date import re from typing import Union from robot.api.deco import keyword, library # Custom type. Extends an existing type but that is not required. class FiDate(date): # Converter function implemented as a classmethod. It could be a normal # function as well, but this way all code is in the same class. @classmethod def from_string(cls, value: str): match = re.match(r'(\d{1,2})\.(\d{1,2})\.(\d{4})$', value) if not match: raise ValueError(f"Expected date in format 'dd.mm.yyyy', got '{value}'.") day, month, year = match.groups() return cls(int(year), int(month), int(day)) # Another custom type. class UsDate(date): @classmethod def from_string(cls, value: str): match = re.match(r'(\d{1,2})/(\d{1,2})/(\d{4})$', value) if not match: raise ValueError(f"Expected date in format 'mm/dd/yyyy', got '{value}'.") month, day, year = match.groups() return cls(int(year), int(month), int(day)) # Register converters using '@library' decorator. @library(converters={FiDate: FiDate.from_string, UsDate: UsDate.from_string}) class Library: # Uses custom converter supporting 'dd.mm.yyyy' format. @keyword def finnish(self, arg: FiDate): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') # Uses custom converter supporting 'mm/dd/yyyy' format. @keyword def us(self, arg: UsDate): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') # Uses IS0-8601 compatible default conversion. @keyword def iso_8601(self, arg: date): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') # Accepts date in different formats. @keyword def any(self, arg: Union[FiDate, UsDate, date]): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Test Case with Named Arguments DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework test case calls the `Sort Words` keyword, demonstrating how named arguments can be used. In the second example, `case_sensitive` is explicitly set to `True`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1a2.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Sort Words Foo bar baZ Sort Words Foo bar baZ case_sensitive=True ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: JSON Variable File Example JSON DESCRIPTION: This JSON snippet shows an example of a JSON variable file used in Robot Framework. It defines string and integer variables that can be imported and used in Robot Framework test cases. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1.rst#_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: JSON CODE: ``` { "STRING": "Hello, world!", "INTEGER": 42 } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using ELSE in TRY/EXCEPT in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to use an ELSE branch in a TRY/EXCEPT block. The ELSE branch is executed if no error occurs in the TRY block. The first example uses specific EXCEPT branches, and the second handles both errors and no errors. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** ELSE branch TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT X Log Error 'X' occurred! EXCEPT Y Log Error 'Y' occurred! ELSE Log No error occurred! END Keyword Outside ``` LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Handle everything TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT AS ${err} Log Error occurred: ${err} ELSE Log No error occurred! END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Custom Argument Conversion in Python for Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to register custom argument converters in Python for Robot Framework libraries, allowing to override default converters and to add support for custom types. The example shows how to parse dates in the 'dd.mm.yyyy' format. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from datetime import date # Converter function. def parse_fi_date(value): day, month, year = value.split('.') return date(int(year), int(month), int(day)) # Register converter function for the specified type. ROBOT_LIBRARY_CONVERTERS = {date: parse_fi_date} # Keyword using custom converter. Converter is got based on argument type. def keyword(arg: date): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Multiple EXCEPT branches in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates multiple EXCEPT branches. The first matching error message will execute the corresponding error handler. ${message} represents a variable containing the error message to match against. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Multiple EXCEPT branches TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT Error message # Try matching this first. Error Handler 1 EXCEPT Another error # Try this if above did not match. Error Handler 2 EXCEPT ${message} # Last match attempt, this time using a variable. Error Handler 3 END Multiple messages with one EXCEPT TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT Error message Another error ${message} # Match any of these. Error handler END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Enabling Automatic Keyword Discovery with @library (Python) DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to enable automatic keyword discovery using the `@library` decorator with the `auto_keywords` argument set to `True`. Requires `robot.api.deco`. The class `Example` represents the library. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api.deco import library @library(scope='GLOBAL', auto_keywords=True) class Example: ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework IF/ELSE Example DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the basic usage of IF/ELSE statements in Robot Framework. It evaluates a condition (`${rc} > 0`) and executes different keywords based on the result. If the condition is true, `Some keyword` is executed; otherwise, `Another keyword` is executed. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0rc1.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example IF ${rc} > 0 Some keyword ELSE Another keyword END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: List and Dictionary Variable Creation with VAR in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the creation of `@{list}` and `&{dict}` variables using the `VAR` syntax in Robot Framework. Demonstrates defining list variables with multiple items and dictionary variables with key-value pairs. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0a2.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** List # Creates a list with three items. VAR @{list} a b c Dictionary # Creates a dict with two items. VAR &{dict} key=value second=item ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework VAR Syntax Example DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework code demonstrates the usage of the new VAR syntax for creating local, suite, test, and global scoped variables dynamically during execution. It creates a local variable `${local}` and a suite-scoped variable `${suite}` and validates their values. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc1.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example # Create a local variable `${local}` with a value `value`. VAR ${local} value # Create a variable that is available throughout the whole suite. # Supported scopes are GLOBAL, SUITE, TEST, TASK and LOCAL (default). VAR ${suite} value scope=SUITE # Validate created variables. Should Be Equal ${local} value Should Be Equal ${suite} value Example continued # Suite level variables are seen also by subsequent tests. Should Be Equal ${suite} value ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Custom Keyword Name using robot_name Attribute DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to set a custom name for a keyword using the `robot_name` attribute. The `login` function's `robot_name` attribute is set to 'Login via user panel', allowing it to be called with that name in Robot Framework test cases. This allows keywords to have more descriptive or user-friendly names. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_19 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def login(username, password): ... login.robot_name = 'Login via user panel' ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Conditional Variable Assignment with IF/ELSE DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates conditional variable assignment using IF/ELSE structures in Robot Framework. It shows both a normal IF/ELSE block and an inline IF/ELSE statement. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc3.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` Normal IF IF 1 > 0 VAR ${x} true value ELSE VAR ${x} false value END Inline IF IF 1 > 0 VAR ${x} true value ELSE VAR ${x} false value ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Updated List/Dictionary Item Access DESCRIPTION: This example illustrates the recommended syntax to access elements within lists and dictionaries using a unified `${var}[item]` approach, irrespective of whether the variable refers to a list or a dictionary. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2.rst#_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` ${var}[item] ${var}[nested][item] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Executing Command and Assertion - Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows a Robot Framework test case that executes a command using the 'Execute Command' keyword and verifies the output with 'Should Be Equal'. It counts the number of '.txt' files and asserts it equals 42. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/TestDataSyntax.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` | *** Test Cases *** | | | | | Escaping Pipe | ${file count} = | Execute Command | ls -1 *.txt \| wc -l | | | Should Be Equal | ${file count} | 42 | ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework New FOR Loop Syntax Example DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the new FOR loop syntax that is used in Robot Framework 4.0 and later versions. It's a more readable and structured way to define loops. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b1.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` FOR ${animal} IN cat dog cow Keyword ${animal} Another keyword END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Enabling Continue-on-Failure with Tags DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to use the `robot:continue-on-failure` tag to make all keywords within a test case or user keyword continuable. Any failures will be treated as continuable failures, and execution will continue. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/TestExecution.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Test 1 Run Keyword and Continue on Failure Should be Equal 1 2 User Keyword 1 Test 2 [Tags] robot:continue-on-failure Should be Equal 1 2 User Keyword 2 *** Keywords *** User Keyword 1 Run Keyword and Continue on Failure Should be Equal 3 4 Log This is executed User Keyword 2 [Tags] robot:continue-on-failure Should be Equal 3 4 Log This is executed ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Converter Accepting Union of Types DESCRIPTION: This code defines a converter that accepts either a string or an integer as input using the `Union` type. It converts integers representing seconds since the Unix epoch to dates and parses strings in the 'dd.mm.yyyy' format. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_19 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from datetime import date import re from typing import Union # Accept both strings and integers. def parse_fi_date(value: Union[str, int]): # Integers are converted separately. if isinstance(value, int): return date.fromtimestamp(value) match = re.match(r'(\d{1,2})\.(\d{1,2})\.(\d{4})$', value) if not match: raise ValueError(f"Expected date in format 'dd.mm.yyyy', got '{value}'.") day, month, year = match.groups() return date(int(year), int(month), int(day)) ROBOT_LIBRARY_CONVERTERS = {date: parse_fi_date} def keyword(arg: date): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using BREAK and CONTINUE in a WHILE Loop DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the use of BREAK and CONTINUE statements within a WHILE loop in Robot Framework. It shows how to exit the loop prematurely or skip to the next iteration based on conditions. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc2.rst#_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Variables *** ${x} 10 *** Test Cases *** BREAK and CONTINUE WHILE True Log ${x} ${x} = Evaluate ${x} - 1 IF ${x} == 0 Log We are done! BREAK END IF ${x} % 2 == 0 CONTINUE # New inline IF. Log Only executed if ${x} is odd. END RETURN Keyword with WHILE using RETURN *** Keywords *** Keyword with WHILE using RETURN WHILE True ${x} = Evaluate ${x} - 1 IF ${x} == 5 RETURN END Fail This is not executed ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Inline IF/ELSE with Assignment Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use inline IF statements for variable assignments. The variable to be assigned must be placed before the IF keyword. If no branch is executed, the variable gets the value `None`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc1.rst#_snippet_22 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keyword *** Inline IF/ELSE with assignment ${var} = IF $condition Keyword argument ELSE Another Keyword Inline IF/ELSE with assignment having multiple variables ${host} ${port} = IF $production Get Production Config ELSE Get Testing Config ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: New FOR Loop Syntax in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet showcases the new FOR loop syntax introduced in Robot Framework 3.1, which uses the `FOR` keyword, standard indentation, and the `END` keyword to define the loop body. This syntax is the only supported syntax in Robot Framework 4.0. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b2.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` FOR ${animal} IN cat dog cow Keyword ${animal} Another keyword END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Multiple EXCEPT Branches in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to use multiple EXCEPT branches to handle different error messages. Each EXCEPT branch is evaluated in order. If `Some Keyword` fails with a message that matches one of the EXCEPT branches, the corresponding error handler is executed. `${message}` must be defined as a variable. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Multiple EXCEPT branches TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT Error message # Try matching this first. Error Handler 1 EXCEPT Another error # Try this if above did not match. Error Handler 2 EXCEPT ${message} # Last match attempt, this time using a variable. Error Handler 3 END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Normal IF Example Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows a normal IF statement. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.rst#_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keyword *** Normal IF IF $condition1 Keyword argument END IF $condition2 RETURN END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Type Hinting with Literal DESCRIPTION: This Python code demonstrates the use of `Literal` type hints to restrict the allowed values for a function argument. Robot Framework validates and converts arguments based on the `Literal` type. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc3.rst#_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def example(arg: Literal['x', 'y', 'z']): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Specifying custom language file in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to activate custom language files in Robot Framework using the `--language` option. The value can be a path to the file or, if in the module search path, the module name. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/TestDataSyntax.rst#_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` robot --language Custom.py tests.robot robot --language MyLang tests.robot ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing Listener as a Module (v3) in Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates a basic listener implemented as a Python module using the listener API version 3. It includes the `start_suite` and `end_test` methods, which print messages when a suite starts and a test ends. This listener is designed to receive notifications about suite and test events during execution. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/ListenerInterface.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def start_suite(data, result): print(f"Suite '{data.name}' starting.") def end_test(data, result): print(f"Test '{result.name}' ended with status {result.status}.") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework with pip DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to install the latest version of Robot Framework using pip. The --pre flag includes pre-release versions, and --upgrade ensures that an existing installation is updated. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.1.3.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Keyword with @keyword Decorator DESCRIPTION: These Python code snippets demonstrates how to use the `@keyword` decorator to explicitly specify argument types for Robot Framework keywords, compatible with both Python 2 and Python 3. The decorator can map argument names to types using a dictionary, or map arguments to types based on position using a list. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1rc1.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @keyword(types={'count': int, 'case_insensitive': bool}) def example_keyword(count, case_insensitive=True): if case_insensitive: # ... ``` LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @keyword(types=[int, bool]) def example_keyword(count, case_insensitive=True): if case_insensitive: # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Variables with a Static Python Class DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates defining variables in a Python class. Variables are created as class and instance attributes. Attributes starting with an underscore or callable attributes are ignored by Robot Framework to prevent methods from being treated as variables. The defined variables are `${VARIABLE}`, `@{LIST}`, and `${ANOTHER VARIABLE}`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/ResourceAndVariableFiles.rst#_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` class StaticExample: variable = 'value' LIST__list = [1, 2, 3] _not_variable = 'starts with an underscore' def __init__(self): self.another_variable = 'another value' ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Calling the Keyword with Multiple Types DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to call a keyword that accepts either an `UnknownType` or an `int`. The example shows that the integer conversion is now attempted even if `UnknownType` is not recognized, a change from previous versions of Robot Framework. This can lead to different behavior if a string value is passed. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1.rst#_snippet_23 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` Example 42 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Registering Multiple Listeners DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to register multiple listeners for a single Robot Framework library. The `ROBOT_LIBRARY_LISTENER` attribute is assigned a list of listener instances. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/ListenerInterface.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from listeners import Listener1, Listener2, Listener3 class LibraryWithMultipleListeners: ROBOT_LIBRARY_LISTENER = [Listener1(), Listener2(), Listener3()] def example_keyword(self): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Test Case with potential false positives using FOR IN ZIP Loop DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework snippet illustrates a test case that uses a `FOR IN ZIP` loop to validate items returned by `Get something`. Due to the default behavior of `FOR IN ZIP`, this test case can produce false positives if `Get something` returns fewer items than expected, but the initial items match the expected values. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1b1.rst#_snippet_18 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Validate something expected 1 expected 2 expected 3 *** Keywords **** Validate something [Arguments] @{expected} @{actual} = Get something FOR ${act} ${exp} IN ZIP ${actual} ${expected} Validate one thing ${act} ${exp} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example keyword with type annotations (Python 3) DESCRIPTION: This Python 3 code snippet shows how to use function annotations to specify argument types for Robot Framework keywords. This allows Robot Framework to automatically convert arguments to the correct type. The arguments `count` and `case_insensitive` will be converted to `int` and `bool` respectively. Requires Python 3 or later. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1b1.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def example_keyword(count: int, case_insensitive: bool = True): if case_insensitive: # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: BREAK and CONTINUE in Robot Framework Loops DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the use of BREAK and CONTINUE statements within FOR loops in Robot Framework, often combined with inline IF statements, to control the flow of the loop based on certain conditions. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example FOR ${x} IN RANGE 1000 IF ${x} > 10 BREAK Log Executed only when ${x} < 11 IF ${x} % 2 == 0 CONTINUE Log Executed only when ${x} is odd. END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using LONGEST Mode with Custom Fill Value DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to use the `fill` option with the `LONGEST` mode in `FOR IN ZIP` loops to specify a custom value to fill in missing values in shorter lists. In this example, missing values are filled with `-`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1rc1.rst#_snippet_24 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Variables *** @{CHARACTERS} a b c d f @{NUMBERS} 1 2 3 *** Test Cases *** LONGEST mode with custom fill value [Documentation] This loop executes five times. ... On last two rounds `${n}` has value `-`. FOR ${c} ${n} IN ZIP ${CHARACTERS} ${NUMBERS} mode=LONGEST fill=- Log ${c}: ${n} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Syntax Examples in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: These examples illustrate using Python syntax with Robot Framework's expression evaluation. They demonstrate string comparisons and substring checks using `${{}}` for inline evaluation. The variables `${VAR}` is first defined and then used in the test case.
