SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_40 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api import TypeInfo def example_keyword(count, case_insensitive): count = TypeInfo.from_type(int).convert(count) if TypeInfo.from_type(bool).convert(case_insensitive): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Basic WHILE Loop Example Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates a basic WHILE loop in Robot Framework that iterates as long as the variable `${x}` is greater than 0. It logs the value of `${x}` in each iteration and decrements it by 1. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Variables *** ${x} 10 *** Test Cases *** Loop as long as condition is True WHILE ${x} > 0 Log ${x} ${x} = Evaluate ${x} - 1 END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: BREAK and CONTINUE in FOR Loop Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the use of BREAK and CONTINUE statements within a FOR loop, combined with inline IF statements, to control loop execution based on specific conditions. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc1.rst#_snippet_23 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example FOR ${x} IN RANGE 1000 IF ${x} > 10 BREAK Log Executed only when ${x} < 11 IF ${x} % 2 == 0 CONTINUE Log Executed only when ${x} is odd. END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Example: run_keyword with optional kwargs DESCRIPTION: This Python example demonstrates the structure of a `run_keyword` method in a remote server. The method takes the keyword name, a list of arguments, and an optional dictionary of keyword arguments (`kwargs`). This allows for handling free named arguments passed from the test data. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/RemoteLibrary.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def run_keyword(name, args, kwargs=None): # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Keywords with Default Arguments in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use keywords with default arguments within Robot Framework test cases. It shows examples of calling `One Default` with and without an argument, and `Multiple Defaults` with varying numbers of arguments, utilizing the default values when arguments are omitted. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_26 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Defaults One Default One Default argument Multiple Defaults required arg Multiple Defaults required arg optional Multiple Defaults required arg optional 1 optional 2 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Importing Libraries Using Import Library Keyword DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to import test libraries using the Import Library keyword from the BuiltIn library. The library name or path and possible arguments are specified similarly to the Library setting. This method is useful when the library is not available at the start of the test execution. Robot Framework will automatically use the registered custom converter `parse_fi_date` to convert the argument to a `datetime.date` object before passing it to the keyword. The first EXCEPT block handles `Error message`, and the second (without any message) handles any other error that occurs. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc1.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Match any after testing more specific errors TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT Error message # Try matching this first Error Handler 1 EXCEPT # Match any that did not match the above. Error Handler 2 END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Normal Variable Syntax in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework example demonstrates using the normal `${variable}` syntax within expressions. It shows examples of comparing a number, checking a string, and searching for a substring. Be aware of the quoting requirements when using this syntax with strings. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/Appendices/EvaluatingExpressions.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Using normal variable syntax Should Be True ${rc} > 0 IF '${status}'.upper() == 'PASS' Log Passed END IF 'FAIL' in r'''${output}''' Log Output contains FAIL END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework IF/ELSE Statement DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates a basic IF/ELSE statement in Robot Framework. It checks if the variable `${rc}` is greater than 0. If true, `Some keyword` is executed. Otherwise, `Another keyword` is executed. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b1.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example IF ${rc} > 0 Some keyword ELSE Another keyword END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing a Robot Framework Preprocessor in Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet presents a parser acting as a preprocessor for Robot Framework data files. It replaces custom headers with standard Robot Framework headers before parsing the data using TestSuite.from_string. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/ParserInterface.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from pathlib import Path from robot.running import TestDefaults, TestSuite class RobotPreprocessor: extension = '.robot' def parse(self, source: Path, defaults: TestDefaults) -> TestSuite: data = source.read_text() for header in 'Settings', 'Variables', 'Test Cases', 'Keywords': data = data.replace(f'=== {header} ===', f'*** {header} ***') suite = TestSuite.from_string(data, defaults=defaults) return suite.config(name=TestSuite.name_from_source(source), source=source) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Test Case Example DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework test case demonstrates how to use a custom keyword that accepts a date in the `dd.mm.yyyy` format. It shows the intended usage of the keyword with a Finnish date. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc2.rst#_snippet_19 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Keyword 11.3.2022 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Specifying Language in Robot Framework Data File DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to specify the language to use in a Robot Framework data file using the `language:` syntax before the first section. This enables localization of keywords and settings within the file. Language code or name can be given. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.0.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` language: fi *** Asetukset *** Dokumentaatio Example using Finnish. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example Keyword Structure in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates a simple keyword structure in Robot Framework. It consists of a keyword `Example` that calls the built-in `Log` keyword twice to log messages to the console. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1b1.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** Example Log Robot Log Framework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Keyword Definition with Embedded Arguments DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to define a Python keyword with embedded arguments using the `@keyword` decorator. This allows for a more natural language syntax when using the keyword in Robot Framework. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc1.rst#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @keyword('Number of ${animals} should be') def example(animals, count): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Keywords with Default Argument Values DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to define Robot Framework keywords with default argument values. The `one_default` function has one argument with a default value, while `multiple_defaults` has one required argument and two optional arguments with default values. This allows for more flexible keyword usage. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_25 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def one_default(arg='default'): print(f"Got argument '{arg}'.") def multiple_defaults(arg1, arg2='default 1', arg3='default 2'): print(f"Got arguments '{arg1}', '{arg2}' and '{arg3}'.") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Basic IF/ELSE syntax in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the basic IF syntax in Robot Framework 4.0, showcasing the use of IF, END, and ELSE markers for conditional execution of keywords. The condition is evaluated in Python and supports variable replacement. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b2.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example IF ${rc} > 0 Some keyword Another keyword END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Custom Date Types and Converters DESCRIPTION: This python snippet demonstrates how to create custom date types (`FiDate`, `UsDate`) and register custom argument converters for them using the `@library` decorator. It shows how to create custom classes that inherit from built-in types and provide their own conversion logic. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_64 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from datetime import date import re from typing import Union from robot.api.deco import keyword, library # Custom type. Extends an existing type but that is not required. class FiDate(date): # Converter function implemented as a classmethod. It could be a normal # function as well, but this way all code is in the same class. @classmethod def from_string(cls, value: str): match = re.match(r'(\d{1,2})\.(\d{1,2})\.(\d{4})$', value) if not match: raise ValueError(f"Expected date in format 'dd.mm.yyyy', got '{value}'.") day, month, year = match.groups() return cls(int(year), int(month), int(day)) # Another custom type. class UsDate(date): @classmethod def from_string(cls, value: str): match = re.match(r'(\d{1,2})/(\d{1,2})/(\d{4})$', value) if not match: raise ValueError(f"Expected date in format 'mm/dd/yyyy', got '{value}'.") month, day, year = match.groups() return cls(int(year), int(month), int(day)) # Register converters using '@library' decorator. @library(converters={FiDate: FiDate.from_string, UsDate: UsDate.from_string}) class Library: # Uses custom converter supporting 'dd.mm.yyyy' format. @keyword def finnish(self, arg: FiDate): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') # Uses custom converter supporting 'mm/dd/yyyy' format. @keyword def us(self, arg: UsDate): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') # Uses IS0-8601 compatible default conversion. @keyword def iso_8601(self, arg: date): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') # Accepts date in different formats. @keyword def any(self, arg: Union[FiDate, UsDate, date]): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Library Keywords with Mixed Arguments in Python DESCRIPTION: Shows how to define a library keyword in Python that accepts both embedded arguments (defined in the `@keyword` decorator) and normal arguments. This allows for more flexible keyword usage in Robot Framework. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0a2.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @keyword('Number of ${animals} should be') def example(animals, count): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Handle everything with ELSE in Robot Framework TRY/EXCEPT DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to combine an EXCEPT block that catches any error with an ELSE block that handles the case when no error occurs. This allows complete handling of both successful and unsuccessful execution of the TRY block. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0a1.rst#_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Handle everything TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT AS ${err} Log Error occurred: ${err} ELSE Log No error occurred! END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Output.xml Keyword Name Format Change DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the change in how keyword names and their owners are stored in output.xml. The `library` attribute is replaced by `owner`, and `sourcename` is replaced by `source_name`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc2.rst#_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` ... ... ... ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Timestamping Output Files in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This command demonstrates how to use the `--timestampoutputs` option to add a timestamp to the output, log, and report files. This can be helpful to differentiate multiple test executions. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/OutputFiles.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` robot --timestampoutputs --log mylog.html --report NONE tests.robot ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Documenting Custom Converters (Python) DESCRIPTION: These Python code snippets show how to add documentation to custom converters. Documentation can be added either to the converter method itself or to the custom type class. This documentation is then used by Libdoc to generate documentation for the library. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc1.rst#_snippet_32 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` class FiDate(date): @classmethod def from_string(cls, value: str): """Date in ``dd.mm.yyyy`` format.""" # ... class UsDate(date): """Date in ``mm/dd/yyyy`` format.""" @classmethod def from_string(cls, value: str): # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework with pip DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to install or upgrade Robot Framework to the latest pre-release version using pip. It installs the newest available release. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.1.2.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Rebot Tool JSON Output DESCRIPTION: Shows the command line example that demonstrates how to use the Rebot tool to create JSON output files from Robot Framework execution results. The `--output` option specifies the output file with a `.json` extension. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc1.rst#_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` rebot --output output.json output.xml ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Enumerating Dictionaries with FOR Loops in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to enumerate dictionary items with their index using FOR IN ENUMERATE loops in Robot Framework. The examples cover both separate variables for index, key, and value, and a single variable containing the index, key, and value. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2rc1.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` FOR ${index} ${key} ${value} IN ENUMERATE &{dict} Log Key is '${key}' and value is '${value}' at index ${index}. END ``` LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` FOR ${item} IN ENUMERATE &{dict} Length Should Be ${item} 3 Log Key is '${item}[1]' and value is '${item}[2]' at index ${item}[0]. END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Union Type Date Conversion DESCRIPTION: This Python code expands the `parse_fi_date` function to accept both strings and integers as input using `typing.Union`. If the input is an integer, it's treated as seconds since the Unix epoch and converted to a date. Otherwise, it's parsed as a `dd.mm.yyyy` formatted date string. Input validation using regex is also included. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc2.rst#_snippet_23 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from datetime import date import re from typing import Union # Accept both strings and integers. def parse_fi_date(value: Union[str, int]): # Integers are converted separately. if isinstance(value, int): return date.fromtimestamp(value) match = re.match(r'(\d{1,2})\.(\d{1,2})\.(\d{4})$', value) if not match: raise ValueError(f"Expected date in format 'dd.mm.yyyy', got '{value}'.") day, month, year = match.groups() return date(int(year), int(month), int(day)) ROBOT_LIBRARY_CONVERTERS = {date: parse_fi_date} def keyword(arg: date): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Resolving keyword conflicts with embedded arguments DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how Robot Framework 6.0 resolves conflicts when multiple keywords with embedded arguments match a given call. It shows a test case and two keyword definitions, where one keyword is a better match than the other. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.0rc1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Automatic conflict resolution Execute "ls" Execute "ls" with "-lh" *** Keywords *** Execute "${cmd}" Log Running command '${cmd}'. Execute "${cmd}" with "${opts}" Log Running command '${cmd}' with options '${opts}'. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: User Keyword with Embedded and Normal Arguments (Robot Framework) DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework code snippet demonstrates how to define a user keyword that combines embedded arguments (in the keyword name) with normal arguments. It demonstrates the scope and persistence of variables within a test suite. The `${var}[item]` syntax works universally for both lists and dictionaries, providing a more consistent and readable approach. This snippet illustrates the preferred method for accessing items in nested data structures. It converts the `count` argument to an integer and checks the truthiness of the `case_insensitive` argument. Execute "${cmd}" with "${opts}" Log Running command '${cmd}' with options '${opts}'. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Inline IF Example Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows an inline IF statement. Documentation can be added to the converter function itself, or to the custom type. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.rst#_snippet_30 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` class FiDate(date): @classmethod def from_string(cls, value: str): """Date in ``dd.mm.yyyy`` format.""" # ... class UsDate(date): """Date in ``mm/dd/yyyy`` format.""" @classmethod def from_string(cls, value: str): # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Libdoc Demonstration Library Source (Python) DESCRIPTION: This example specifies that the source code for the library is located at src/SupportingTools/LoggingLibrary.py and refers to it as a realistic example. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/SupportingTools/Libdoc.rst#_snippet_23 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` src/SupportingTools/LoggingLibrary.py ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: List Expansion with Item Access Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates list expansion with item access using the `@{var}[items]` syntax in Robot Framework. The variable `${var}` is assumed to have a value that is a dictionary containing an 'items' key with a list as its value. The loop iterates through the list accessed via the dictionary key 'items', logging each item. Prior to Robot Framework 4.0, this required multiple lines of code. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b3.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` FOR ${item} IN @{var}[items] Log ${item} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Inline IF Statements in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates the use of inline IF statements in Robot Framework, including ELSE and ELSE IF branches. It shows the concise syntax for executing single statements conditionally. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc2.rst#_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keyword *** Normal IF IF $condition1 Keyword argument END IF $condition2 RETURN END Inline IF IF $condition1 Keyword argument IF $condition2 RETURN ``` LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keyword *** Inline IF/ELSE IF $condition Keyword argument ELSE Another Keyword Inline IF/ELSE IF/ELSE IF $cond1 Keyword 1 ELSE IF $cond2 Keyword 2 ELSE IF $cond3 Keyword 3 ELSE Keyword 4 ``` LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keyword *** Inline IF/ELSE with assignment ${var} = IF $condition Keyword argument ELSE Another Keyword Inline IF/ELSE with assignment having multiple variables ${host} ${port} = IF $production Get Production Config ELSE Get Testing Config ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Suite Statistics Level - Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to control the depth of test suite levels displayed in the `Statistics by Suite` table using the `--suitestatlevel` command-line option. The argument specifies the number of suite levels to show. A value of 3 shows the top 3 levels. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/OutputFiles.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` --suitestatlevel 3 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Date Converter (dd.mm.yyyy) DESCRIPTION: This python snippet demonstrates a custom argument converter that parses a date string in the format `dd.mm.yyyy` and converts it into a `datetime.date` object. The `ROBOT_LIBRARY_CONVERTERS` dictionary registers this converter to be used when a function expects a `date` type argument. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_59 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from datetime import date # Converter function. def parse_fi_date(value): day, month, year = value.split('.') return date(int(year), int(month), int(day)) # Register converter function for the specified type. ROBOT_LIBRARY_CONVERTERS = {date: parse_fi_date} # Keyword using custom converter. Converter is resolved based on argument type. def keyword(arg: date): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using ELSE Branch in Robot Framework TRY/EXCEPT DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the use of an ELSE branch in a TRY/EXCEPT block. The ELSE branch is executed if the TRY block completes without any errors. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc2.rst#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** ELSE branch TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT X Log Error 'X' occurred! EXCEPT Y Log Error 'Y' occurred! ELSE Log No error occurred! END Keyword Outside ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Custom Argument Conversion with Validation in Python DESCRIPTION: Shows how to validate input values within a custom argument converter in Python for Robot Framework. The example uses regular expressions to validate the date format and raises a ValueError with a user-friendly message if the input is invalid. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from datetime import date import re def parse_fi_date(value): # Validate input using regular expression and raise ValueError if not valid. match = re.match(r'(\d{1,2})\.([0-9]{1,2})\.([0-9]{4})$', value) if not match: raise ValueError(f"Expected date in format 'dd.mm.yyyy', got '{value}'.") day, month, year = match.groups() return date(int(year), int(month), int(day)) ROBOT_LIBRARY_CONVERTERS = {date: parse_fi_date} def keyword(arg: date): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Flattening Keyword Structures with 'robot:flatten' Tag in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework example demonstrates how to flatten keyword structures during execution using the `robot:flatten` tag. This reduces the size of the output.xml file and simplifies the log file by removing nested keyword structures, preserving the log messages from the child keywords. The `Example` keyword will have its child keywords flattened in the output XML. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1rc1.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** Example [Tags] robot:flatten Log Robot Log Framework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Improved Public API for Languages DESCRIPTION: This enhancement makes the public `robot.api.Languages` API easier to use for external tools. This simplifies the process of integrating Robot Framework's language support into other applications. The first command installs the latest pre-release version, while the second installs a specific version (3.2rc2). It shows returning values at the end of a keyword, returning values conditionally, and exiting the keyword prematurely. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc1.rst#_snippet_24 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** Return at the end Some Keyword ${result} = Another Keyword RETURN ${result} Return conditionally IF ${condition} RETURN Something ELSE RETURN Something else END Early return IF ${not applicable} RETURN Some Keyword Another Keyword ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework User Keyword with Varargs and Named Arguments DESCRIPTION: Defines a Robot Framework user keyword that accepts variable number of arguments (`@{varargs}`) and a named argument (`${named}`). SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1rc2.rst#_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** With Varargs [Arguments] @{varargs} ${named} Log Many @{varargs} ${named} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: RETURN in WHILE Loop Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use the RETURN statement in a WHILE loop in Robot Framework to exit the entire user keyword prematurely. If the condition `${x} == 5` is met, the RETURN statement is executed, and the keyword exits without executing the `Fail` keyword. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc1.rst#_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** Keyword with WHILE using RETURN WHILE True ${x} = Evaluate ${x} - 1 IF ${x} == 5 RETURN END Fail This is not executed ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Test Case with Named-Only Arguments DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework test case demonstrates how to call a Python keyword that uses named-only arguments. The `case_sensitive` argument is passed by name. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1rc1.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Sort Words Foo bar baZ Sort Words Foo bar baZ case_sensitive=True ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Test Cases Using Keyword-Only Arguments DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework test case demonstrates the usage of keywords with keyword-only arguments. It calls the `Sort Words` and `Strip Spaces` keywords, showcasing how to pass values to the keyword-only arguments. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_34 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Sort Words Foo bar baZ Sort Words Foo bar baZ case_sensitive=True Strip Spaces ${word} left=False ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Listener V3 - start_library_keyword DESCRIPTION: Example of a listener version 3 that prints information about the executed keyword and the library it belongs to. It accesses the library instance to inspect its state, including the library name, source, line number, scope, and current instance. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0b1.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.running import Keyword as KeywordData, LibraryKeyword from robot.result import Keyword as KeywordResult def start_library_keyword(data: KeywordData, implementation: LibraryKeyword, result: KeywordResult): library = implementation.owner print(f"Keyword '{implementation.name}' is implemented in library " f"'{library.name}' at '{implementation.source}' on line " f"{implementation.lineno}. The library has {library.scope.name} " f"scope and the current instance is {library.instance}.") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using JSON Variable File RobotFramework DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework snippet demonstrates how to use a JSON variable file. It imports the variables from the `example.json` file and then uses them in a test case to verify their values. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1.rst#_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Variables example.json *** Test Cases *** Example Should Be Equal ${STRING} Hello, world! Should Be Equal ${INTEGER} ${42} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Strict Type Validation with None Converter DESCRIPTION: This python snippet shows an alternative way to achieve strict type validation by setting the converter for a custom type to `None`. This has the same effect as the previous example, ensuring that the keyword only accepts arguments of the specified type. This is a more concise approach introduced in Robot Framework 6.0. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_66 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` class StrictType: pass ROBOT_LIBRARY_CONVERTERS = {StrictType: None} def example(argument: StrictType): assert isinstance(argument, StrictType) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: ZIP Loop Modes in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the different modes available for ZIP loops in Robot Framework: STRICT, SHORTEST, and LONGEST, including custom fill values. Shows how list lengths impact loop execution based on the selected mode. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1b1.rst#_snippet_19 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` @{CHARACTERS} a b c d f @{NUMBERS} 1 2 3 *** Test Cases *** STRICT mode [Documentation] This loop fails due to lists lengths being different. FOR ${c} ${n} IN ZIP ${CHARACTERS} ${NUMBERS} mode=STRICT Log ${c}: ${n} END SHORTEST mode [Documentation] This loop executes three times. FOR ${c} ${n} IN ZIP ${CHARACTERS} ${NUMBERS} mode=SHORTEST Log ${c}: ${n} END LONGEST mode [Documentation] This loop executes five times. ... On last two rounds `${n}` has value `None`. FOR ${c} ${n} IN ZIP ${CHARACTERS} ${NUMBERS} mode=LONGEST Log ${c}: ${n} END LONGEST mode with custom fill value [Documentation] This loop executes five times. ... On last two rounds `${n}` has value `-`. FOR ${c} ${n} IN ZIP ${CHARACTERS} ${NUMBERS} mode=LONGEST fill=- Log ${c}: ${n} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Listener v3 example: start_keyword and end_while DESCRIPTION: This Python code defines a Robot Framework listener that prints information about started keywords and ended WHILE loops. It utilizes the `KeywordData`, `KeywordResult`, `WhileData`, and `WhileResult` classes from the `robot.running` and `robot.result` modules to access keyword and loop data. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.running import Keyword as KeywordData, While as WhileData from robot.result import Keyword as KeywordResult, While as WhileResult def start_keyword(data: KeywordData, result: KeywordResult): print(f"Keyword '{result.full_name}' used on line {data.lineno} started.") def end_while(data: WhileData, result: WhileResult): print(f"WHILE loop on line {data.lineno} ended with status {result.status} " f"after {len(result.body)} iterations.") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example Listener (version 2) Writing to File DESCRIPTION: This example implements a listener that writes all information to a text file in a temporary directory. The filename can be given from the command line with a default value. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/ListenerInterface.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` import os.path import tempfile class Example: ROBOT_LISTENER_API_VERSION = 2 def __init__(self, file_name='listen.txt'): path = os.path.join(tempfile.gettempdir(), file_name) self.file = open(path, 'w') def start_suite(self, name, attrs): self.file.write("%s '%s'\n" % (name, attrs['doc'])) def start_test(self, name, attrs): ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Nested FOR and IF Loops DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to nest FOR and IF loops in Robot Framework. It iterates through rows and cells in a data structure, and processes each cell if it's not equal to "IGNORE". SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b1.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` FOR ${row} IN @{rows} FOR ${cell} IN @{row} IF "${cell}" != "IGNORE" Process Cell ${cell} END END END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Generating XML Spec with HTML documentation DESCRIPTION: This snippet generates an XML spec file for a library, explicitly setting the format to XML and documentation format to HTML using the `--format` and `-s` option. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/SupportingTools/Libdoc.rst#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` libdoc --format xml -s html MyLibrary MyLibrary.xml ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Excluding Tests with Reserved Tag DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to use the `robot:exclude` reserved tag to unconditionally exclude test cases. Also shows how to dynamically exclude tests using a variable containing the reserved tag. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/ConfiguringExecution.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Variables *** ${EXCLUDE} robot:exclude *** Test Cases *** Literal [Documentation] Unconditionally excluded. [Tags] robot:exclude Log This is not executed As variable [Documentation] Excluded unless ${EXCLUDE} is set to a different value. [Tags] ${EXCLUDE} Log This is not executed by default ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using @library decorator to set library scope and version in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: The `@library` decorator provides a convenient way to set library scope, version, documentation format, and listener. It replaces the need to define `ROBOT_LIBRARY_SCOPE` and `ROBOT_LIBRARY_VERSION` as class attributes. It is necessary to import `library` from `robot.api.deco`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api.deco import library @library(scope='GLOBAL', version='3.2b1') class NewWay: # actual library code class OldWay: ROBOT_LIBRARY_SCOPE = 'GLOBAL' ROBOT_LIBRARY_VERSION = '3.2b1' # actual library code ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing Nested List and Dictionary Items in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates the new syntax for accessing nested list and dictionary variable items in Robot Framework 3.1. It allows accessing deeply nested items using the `${var}[key][0]` syntax, which is useful when working with JSON objects commonly used with REST interfaces. The old syntax `@{var}[0]` and `&{var}[key]` still works but it will be `deprecated in the future`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1rc2.rst#_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` ${var}[key][0] ``` LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` ${var}[0] ``` LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` ${var}[key] ``` LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` @{var}[0] ``` LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` &{var}[key] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Keywords with @library and @keyword Decorators (Python) DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use the `@library` decorator in conjunction with the `@keyword` decorator to explicitly define which methods in a library class should be treated as Robot Framework keywords. This enforces a more explicit keyword definition. Requires `robot.api.deco.library` and `robot.api.deco.keyword`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2b1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api.deco import library, keyword @library class Example: @keyword def example_keyword(self): # ... def not_keyword(self): # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Output.xml Timestamp Format Change (XML) DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates the change in timestamp format within the output.xml file. The older format, `YYYYMMDD HH:MM:SS.mmm`, is replaced with the ISO 8601 compatible format `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.mmmmmm`. In addition, `starttime` and `endtime` attributes are replaced with `start` and `elapsed`, and `timestamp` is replaced with `time`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0a2.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` Hello world! Hello world! ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Evaluate Keyword with Nested Module in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates a workaround for accessing nested modules, specifically `selenium.webdriver.ChromeOptions`, using the `Evaluate` keyword and the `modules` argument. This resolves issues where importing the root module doesn't automatically import submodules. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/Appendices/EvaluatingExpressions.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Does not work due to nested module structure Log ${{selenium.webdriver.ChromeOptions()}} Evaluate keyword with nested module ${options} = Evaluate selenium.webdriver.ChromeOptions() modules=selenium.webdriver Log ${options} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Run tests with python -m robot (Python) DESCRIPTION: This command executes Robot Framework tests using the Python module execution feature. This is particularly useful when working with multiple Python interpreters, such as `python3`, `jython`, or `ipy`. A limitation is that it does not work with Python 2.6. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.0a2.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` python -m robot ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Output.xml Keyword Name Change (XML) DESCRIPTION: This snippet showcases the change in how keyword names are stored within the output.xml file. The `library` attribute for keywords, which previously indicated the library or resource file, is now replaced with the `owner` attribute. Also, `sourcename` attribute, holding original name stored with keywords using embedded arguments, is renamed to `source_name`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0a2.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` ... ... ... ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: BREAK and CONTINUE Example Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates the use of `BREAK` and `CONTINUE` statements within a `WHILE` loop in Robot Framework. It shows how to exit the loop prematurely using `BREAK` when a condition is met and how to skip iterations using `CONTINUE` based on another condition. Requires Robot Framework. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.rst#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Variables *** ${x} 10 *** Test Cases *** BREAK and CONTINUE WHILE True Log ${x} ${x} = Evaluate ${x} - 1 IF ${x} == 0 Log We are done! BREAK END IF ${x} % 2 == 0 CONTINUE # New inline IF. Log Only executed if ${x} is odd. END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Dictionary Variable Usage - Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use a dictionary variable in Robot Framework. The first example passes individual key-value pairs as named arguments to a keyword. The second example passes the entire dictionary as a single argument using the `&{DICT}` syntax. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-2.9.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example 1 My Keyword key=value second=2 third=${3} Example 2 My Keyword &{DICT} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating TestSuite from JSON data using from_json() - Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to create a Robot Framework TestSuite object from JSON data using the `from_json()` method. It shows creating a suite from a JSON file and from a JSON string. Dependencies: robot.running.TestSuite. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1rc1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from robot.running import TestSuite # Create suite from JSON data in a file. suite = TestSuite.from_json('data.rbt') # Create suite from a JSON string. suite = TestSuite.from_json('{"name": "Suite", "tests": [{"name": "Test"}]}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Assigning Keyword Return Values to List and Dictionary Items in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework example demonstrates how to assign the return values from keywords to list and dictionary items. This allows for more direct manipulation of data structures within Robot Framework tests. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1rc1.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` ${list}[0] = Keyword ${dict}[key] = Keyword ${result}[users][0] = Keyword ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Returning Object Value from Keyword Python DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates returning an object from a keyword, enabling access to its attributes in Robot Framework using extended variable syntax. It assumes `MyObject` is a class defined in `mymodule`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_91 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from mymodule import MyObject def return_object(name): return MyObject(name) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using JSON Variable File in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to use a JSON variable file in Robot Framework. The `Variables` setting specifies the path to the JSON file, and the variables defined in the file can be used in test cases. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1b1.rst#_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Variables example.json *** Test Cases *** Example Should Be Equal ${STRING} Hello, world! Should Be Equal ${INTEGER} ${42} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Adding Groups Programmatically DESCRIPTION: This Python code shows how to programmatically add a group with two keywords to the end of each test using a pre-run modifier. It demonstrates using the Robot Framework API to manipulate the test structure. This uses `robot.api` SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.2.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api import SuiteVisitor class GroupAdder(SuiteVisitor): def start_test(self, test): group = test.body.create_group(name='Example') group.body.create_keyword(name='Log', args=['Hello, world!']) group.body.create_keyword(name='No Operation') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using BuiltIn Library in Python DESCRIPTION: This Python snippet shows how to use the `BuiltIn` library in Robot Framework to access variables and detect if Robot Framework is running. It's important to register methods that use `run_keyword` variants as *run keywords*. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_108 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import os.path from robot.libraries.BuiltIn import BuiltIn def do_something(argument): builtin = BuiltIn() output = do_something_that_creates_a_lot_of_output(argument) if builtin.robot_running: output_dir = builtin.replace_variables('${OUTPUT_DIR}') else: output_dir = '.' with open(os.path.join(output_dir, 'output.txt'), 'w') as file: file.write(output) print('*HTML* Output written to output.txt') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Keyword Flattening Example DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to flatten keywords using the `robot:flatten` tag within a Robot Framework keyword definition. When executed, the keyword's content (except for log messages) will be removed during parsing, and only the log messages will be retained in the output file. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/OutputFiles.rst#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** Example [Tags] robot:flatten Log Keywords and the loop are removed, but logged messages are preserved. FOR ${i} IN RANGE 1 101 Log Iteration ${i}/100. END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Disabling Automatic Keyword Exposure (Class-Based Library - Python) DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to disable automatic keyword exposure in a class-based Robot Framework library by setting the `ROBOT_AUTO_KEYWORDS` attribute to `False`. Only methods decorated with `@keyword` will be exposed as keywords. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` class Example: ROBOT_AUTO_KEYWORDS = False ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework ZIP Loop Example DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates the default behavior of the FOR IN ZIP loop in Robot Framework, where iteration stops when the shortest list is exhausted. Items from longer lists are ignored. This can lead to unexpected behavior if the lengths of the lists are not carefully managed. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1.rst#_snippet_18 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Variables *** @{ANIMALS} dog cat horse cow elephant @{ELIMET} koira kissa *** Test Cases *** Example FOR ${en} ${fi} IN ZIP ${ANIMALS} ${ELIMET} Log ${en} is ${fi} in Finnish END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using the @not_keyword decorator DESCRIPTION: This code snippet illustrates the usage of the `@not_keyword` decorator to prevent a function or method from being recognized as a Robot Framework keyword. This is useful for excluding helper functions or methods from being exposed as keywords. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2rc1.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from robot.api.deco import not_keyword def example_keyword(self): # ... @not_keyword def not_exposed_as_keyword(self): # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Simple Pattern Examples for Test Matching DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates using simple patterns to match test cases based on their names or tags. These patterns support wildcards like `*` and `?`, and character sets using brackets, and the matching is case, space, and underscore insensitive. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/BasicUsage.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` --test Example* # Matches tests with name starting 'Example'. --test Example[1-2] # Matches tests 'Example1' and 'Example2'. --include f?? # Matches tests with a tag that starts with 'f' is three characters long. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Argument Conversion Example in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the change in argument conversion logic in Robot Framework 6.1. Previously, unrecognized types would prevent further conversion attempts. Now, unrecognized types are skipped, allowing subsequent conversion attempts to proceed. The example shows a Python function with a `Union` type hint, and how the argument `42` is now correctly converted to an integer. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1a1.rst#_snippet_18 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` def example(arg: Union[UnknownType, int]): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: New Style For Loop Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the new-style for loop syntax in Robot Framework, which is the recommended approach. The loop starts with `FOR`, does not require escaping keywords inside the loop, and is explicitly closed with an `END` marker. This syntax is more readable and maintainable than the old style and avoids deprecation warnings. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2b1.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` | FOR | ${x} | IN | 1 | 2 | | Log | ${x} | END | ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Serializing TestSuite to JSON using to_json DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to serialize a Robot Framework TestSuite object to JSON data, both as a string and to a file with custom indentation. It relies on the `robot.running` module for TestSuite management and file system operations. The resulting JSON can be used for data transfer, storage, or alternative data formats. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from robot.running import TestSuite # Construct suite based on data on the file system. suite = TestSuite.from_file_system('/path/to/data') # Get JSON data as a string. data = suite.to_json() # Save JSON data to a file with custom indentation. suite.to_json('data.rbt', indent=2) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Test Case Example of String Arguments DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework test case illustrates that arguments are passed as Unicode strings by default when no type information is provided. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_38 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Example Keyword 42 False ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Removing Globally Set Tags with `-tag` Syntax in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to remove tags that are set globally (e.g., in the Settings section) from individual tests using the `-tag` syntax. This allows for more granular control over tag assignment at the test case level. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0a2.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Test Tags all most *** Test Cases *** T1 No Operation T2 [Tags] one -most No Operation T3 No Operation ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Install Dependencies - npm DESCRIPTION: This command installs the necessary dependencies for the project using npm. It downloads and installs the packages defined in the `package.json` file. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/src/web/README.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` npm install ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Path Handling Update in Listener Version 3 Methods in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet describes how paths passed to listener version 3 methods (`output_file`, `log_file`) have changed from strings to `pathlib.Path` objects. If string representation is required, the path can be converted by using `str(path)`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc2.rst#_snippet_18 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` str(path) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Tasks Header DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to define tasks instead of test cases by using the `*** Tasks ***` header. This activates the RPA mode, causing reports and logs to use the term "task" instead of "test". SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1a2.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Tasks *** Example Task Log Hello, Task! ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework ELSE IF Example DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use ELSE IF branches in Robot Framework. It evaluates multiple conditions sequentially and executes the block corresponding to the first true condition. If none of the conditions are true, the optional ELSE block is executed. The example uses the `$rc` variable format to ensure the variable's value is used directly in the condition evaluation. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0rc1.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example IF $rc > 0 Positive keyword ELSE IF $rc < 0 Negative keyword ELSE IF $rc == 0 Zero keyword ELSE Fail Unexpected rc: ${rc} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing a Simple External Parser DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates a simple external parser for Robot Framework. It defines a module-level `parse` function that takes a source file path and returns a `TestSuite` object. The `EXTENSION` variable specifies the file extension handled by the parser. It uses the `robot.api` module to create the test suite. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from robot.api import TestSuite EXTENSION = '.example' def parse(source): suite = TestSuite(name='Example', source=source) test = suite.tests.create(name='Test') test.body.create_keyword(name='Log', args=['Hello!']) return suite ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Old Style For Loop Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the old-style for loop syntax in Robot Framework, which has been deprecated in version 3.2 when using the pipe-separated format. The loop starts with `:FOR` and each line inside the loop is escaped with a backslash. The use of this syntax will trigger deprecation warnings and is scheduled for removal in future versions. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2b1.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` | :FOR | ${x} | IN | 1 | 2 | | Log | ${x} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: New Style FOR Loop Example DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the new-style FOR loop syntax in Robot Framework, which is recommended for Robot Framework 3.2 and later. It includes the FOR keyword and an explicit END marker. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2rc1.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` | FOR | ${x} | IN | 1 | 2 | | Log | ${x} | END | ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Keyword Structure Without Flattening XML DESCRIPTION: This XML snippet illustrates the structure of the `output.xml` file when a keyword is executed without flattening. It shows the nested structure created by the `Log` keywords within the `Example` keyword. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` Robot Logs the given message with the given level. Robot Framework Logs the given message with the given level. Framework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Create Robot Framework Test Suite from JSON (Python) DESCRIPTION: This Python code snippet demonstrates how to create a Robot Framework test suite from JSON data using the `TestSuite.from_json` method. The suite is loaded from a JSON file named 'tests.rbt'. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1a1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from robot.api import TestSuite suite = TestSuite.from_json('tests.rbt') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: XML output of Simple Keyword DESCRIPTION: The XML output that is generated when the simple keyword is run. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1a1.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: XML CODE: ``` Robot Logs the given message with the given level. Robot Framework Logs the given message with the given level. Framework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Specific Robot Framework Version DESCRIPTION: This command installs a specific version of Robot Framework (5.0a1) using pip. This is useful for testing or using a specific pre-release version of the framework. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0a1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==5.0a1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing a Specific Robot Framework Version with pip DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to install a specific version of Robot Framework using pip. By specifying `robotframework==7.2.1`, the installer will ensure that exactly version 7.2.1 is installed, avoiding any potential compatibility issues with newer releases. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.2.1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Text CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==7.2.1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Set Local Variable Keyword Addition (Robot Framework) DESCRIPTION: This snippet refers to the addition of the `Set Local Variable` keyword. This enhancement provides a way to set variables within the local scope of a keyword, improving code organization and preventing variable conflicts. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2b1.rst#_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Inline IF/ELSE with multiple variable assignment Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows an inline IF/ELSE statement with multiple variable assignment. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.rst#_snippet_18 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keyword *** Inline IF/ELSE with assignment having multiple variables ${host} ${port} = IF $production Get Production Config ELSE Get Testing Config ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Automatic argument conversion with Python 3 annotations DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to use Python 3 function annotations to specify argument types for Robot Framework keywords. Robot Framework will automatically convert the arguments to the specified types. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def example_keyword(count: int, case_insensitive: bool = True): if case_insensitive: # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Custom Type Conversion in Python DESCRIPTION: This Python code defines custom date types (FiDate and UsDate) and their corresponding conversion functions. It uses the `@library` decorator to register these converters for use in Robot Framework keywords. The example highlights the creation of custom types extending existing types. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_21 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from datetime import date import re from typing import Union from robot.api.deco import keyword, library # Custom type. Extends an existing type but that is not required. class FiDate(date): # Converter function implemented as a classmethod. It could be a normal # function as well, but this way all code is in the same class. @classmethod def from_string(cls, value: str): match = re.match(r'(\d{1,2})\.(\d{1,2})\.(\d{4})$', value) if not match: raise ValueError(f"Expected date in format 'dd.mm.yyyy', got '{value}'.") day, month, year = match.groups() return cls(int(year), int(month), int(day)) # Another custom type. class UsDate(date): @classmethod def from_string(cls, value: str): match = re.match(r'(\d{1,2})/(\d{1,2})/(\d{4})$', value) if not match: raise ValueError(f"Expected date in format 'mm/dd/yyyy', got '{value}'.") month, day, year = match.groups() return cls(int(year), int(month), int(day)) # Register converters using '@library' decorator. @library(converters={FiDate: FiDate.from_string, UsDate: UsDate.from_string}) class Library: # Uses custom converter supporting 'dd.mm.yyyy' format. @keyword def finnish(self, arg: FiDate): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') # Uses custom converter supporting 'mm/dd/yyyy' format. @keyword def us(self, arg: UsDate): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') # Uses IS0-8601 compatible default conversion. @keyword def iso_8601(self, arg: date): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') # Accepts date in different formats. @keyword def any(self, arg: Union[FiDate, UsDate, date]): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Command Line Search for Deprecated List Access DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to use the `pss` tool to search for the deprecated list item access syntax `@{var}[item]` in Robot Framework test data files. The `-ai` option performs a case-insensitive search. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2b1.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` pss -ai "@\{.+\}\[" path/to/tests ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Explicit exact match in Robot Framework EXCEPT DESCRIPTION: This example uses the EQUALS: prefix to ensure an exact match of the error message in the EXCEPT branch. This is the default behavior if no prefix is specified. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0a1.rst#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Explicit exact match TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT EQUALS: ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'ooops' Error Handler EXCEPT EQUALS: Error 13 occurred Error Handler 2 END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Rebot Usage Example DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates different ways to use Rebot with XML output files. Each branch can contain multiple statements. This is relevant for Robot Framework's ability to handle Enum types for argument conversion and documentation generation by Libdoc. NORTH = auto() NORTH_WEST = auto() def kw(arg: Direction): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Listener example: Print keyword and library info (Python) DESCRIPTION: This Python code shows how to access library information within a listener function. It uses `robot.running` and `robot.result` to extract details such as the library name, source, scope, and instance related to an executed keyword. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc3.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.running import Keyword as KeywordData, LibraryKeyword from robot.result import Keyword as KeywordResult def start_library_keyword(data: KeywordData, implementation: LibraryKeyword, result: KeywordResult): library = implementation.owner print(f"Keyword '{implementation.name}' is implemented in library " f"'{library.name}' at '{implementation.source}' on line " f"{implementation.lineno}. The library has {library.scope.name} " f"scope and the current instance is {library.instance}.") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework 3.2 rc1 using pip DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to install the Robot Framework 3.2 release candidate 1 using the pip package installer. It shows the use of the `--pre` and `--upgrade` flags for installing the latest pre-release, and a specific version installation. This allows specifying suite setup and teardown for the root suite. One version takes only the keyword name and a list of arguments, while the other includes a map for keyword arguments. This approach supports backwards compatibility and allows for handling named arguments. It enhances how Robot Framework identifies library classes. It replaces the old '[Return]' setting and 'Return From Keyword' keywords. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** Return at the end Some Keyword ${result} = Another Keyword RETURN ${result} Return conditionally IF ${condition} RETURN Something ELSE RETURN Something else END Early return IF ${not applicable} RETURN Some Keyword Another Keyword ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Capturing Error Message in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This code snippet illustrates how to capture the error message into a variable using the `AS ${var}` syntax in the EXCEPT block. The captured error message can then be used within the error handling keyword. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Capture error TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT GLOB: ValueError: * AS ${error} Error Handler 1 ${error} EXCEPT REGEXP: [Ee]rror \\d+ GLOB: ${pattern} AS ${error} Error Handler 2 ${error} EXCEPT AS ${error} Error Handler 3 ${error} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implicit Argument Type Conversion from Default Values - Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how Robot Framework infers argument types based on default values. In this example, 'count' is inferred as 'int' and 'case_insensitive' as 'bool'. The file path is relative to the root directory of the user guide. This is used to include examples in the documentation.
