SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/ResourceAndVariableFiles.rst#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import math as _math def _get_area(diameter): radius = diameter / 2.0 area = _math.pi * radius * radius return area AREA1 = _get_area(1) AREA2 = _get_area(2) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Variable Definition with Line Continuation DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to define a long string variable in Robot Framework, splitting it across multiple lines using the `...` continuation marker. The lines are joined together with a space by default. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc1.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Long value VAR ${long} ... This value is rather long. ... It has been split to multiple lines. ... Parts will be joined together with a space. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Support for Micro and Nanosecond Time Strings DESCRIPTION: This enhancement adds support to parse time strings containing micro and nanoseconds, such as `100 ns`. This allows for more precise time-related operations within tests. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.0.rst#_snippet_13 ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing a Parser Module in Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates a simple parser implemented as a Python module. It defines the EXTENSION and a parse function that creates a dummy test suite with one test case. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/ParserInterface.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api import TestSuite EXTENSION = '.example' def parse(source): suite = TestSuite(name='Example', source=source) test = suite.tests.create(name='Test') test.body.create_keyword(name='Log', args=['Hello!']) return suite ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Define Robot Framework Keyword DESCRIPTION: This code snippet defines a Robot Framework keyword named `Suite Setup`. The keyword logs the value of the variable `${msg}` to the console. This keyword is designed to be called during suite setup to verify basic setup functionality. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/atest/testdata/parsing/data_formats/rest/with_init/__init__.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` ** Keywords ** Suite Setup Log ${msg} # No more arguments! ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Documenting Converter Functions with Type Hints in Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to document converter functions using type hints, and the documentation will be automatically included in Libdoc outputs. It demonstrates adding documentation to converter functions that are registered for existing types. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_68 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` class FiDate(date): @classmethod def from_string(cls, value: str): """Date in ``dd.mm.yyyy`` format.""" ... class UsDate(date): """Date in ``mm/dd/yyyy`` format.""" @classmethod def from_string(cls, value: str): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: WHILE Loop Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates the use of the WHILE loop in Robot Framework, which executes as long as the specified condition is true. It uses the Evaluate keyword to decrement a variable and the Log keyword to print its value during each iteration. The loop condition is evaluated in Python, allowing the use of variables and built-in functions. BREAK is used to exit the loop, and CONTINUE is used to skip to the next iteration, often in conjunction with inline IF statements. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0a1.rst#_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Variables *** ${x} 10 *** Test Cases *** Loop as long as condition is True WHILE ${x} > 0 Log ${x} ${x} = Evaluate ${x} - 1 END BREAK and CONTINUE WHILE True Log ${x} ${x} = Evaluate ${x} - 1 IF ${x} == 0 Log We are done! BREAK END IF ${x} % 2 == 0 CONTINUE # New inline IF. Log Only executed if ${x} is odd. END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Basic TRY/EXCEPT in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates the basic usage of the TRY/EXCEPT syntax in Robot Framework for handling specific error messages. If 'Some Keyword' fails with the message 'Error message', then 'Error Handler Keyword' is executed. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0a1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** First example TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT Error message Error Handler Keyword END Keyword Outside ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Executing multiple test files with custom name DESCRIPTION: Shows how to execute multiple Robot Framework test case files, and how to override the default top-level suite name using the `--name` option. This is useful when the default name generated by concatenating the file names is too long or complicated. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/BasicUsage.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` robot my_tests.robot your_tests.robot robot --name Example path/to/tests/pattern_*.robot ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Collections: Get From Dictionary default value DESCRIPTION: The `Get From Dictionary` keyword now accepts a default value if the key is missing. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.0.rst#_snippet_19 ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring System Log in Bash DESCRIPTION: This bash script configures the Robot Framework system log by setting the `ROBOT_SYSLOG_FILE` environment variable to specify the log file path and the `ROBOT_SYSLOG_LEVEL` environment variable to set the log level. The script then executes a Robot Framework test suite. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/OutputFiles.rst#_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` #!/bin/bash export ROBOT_SYSLOG_FILE=/tmp/syslog.txt export ROBOT_SYSLOG_LEVEL=DEBUG robot --name Syslog_example path/to/tests ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Nested FOR and IF/ELSE Loops in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework example showcases nested FOR loops with an IF/ELSE structure inside. It iterates through rows and cells, processing each cell unless its value is 'IGNORE'. This demonstrates the ability to nest control structures, a feature added in Robot Framework 4.0. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` FOR ${row} IN @{rows} FOR ${cell} IN @{row} IF "${cell}" != "IGNORE" Process Cell ${cell} END END END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Limiting WHILE Loop Iterations DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to limit the number of iterations in a WHILE loop using the `limit` parameter. It shows examples of limiting by iteration count, time, and disabling the limit. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc2.rst#_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Limit as iteration count WHILE True limit=100 Log This is run 100 times. END Limit as time WHILE True limit=10 seconds Log This is run 10 seconds. END No limit WHILE True limit=NONE Log This must be forcefully stopped. END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Keyword with Type Hints (Python 3) DESCRIPTION: This Python 3 code shows how to use function annotations to explicitly specify argument types for Robot Framework keywords. This allows Robot Framework to automatically convert arguments to the specified types. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1rc1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def example_keyword(count: int, case_insensitive: bool = True): if case_insensitive: # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Listener v3 example: start_library_keyword DESCRIPTION: This Python code defines a Robot Framework listener that prints information about the executed keyword and the library it belongs to. It accesses the library name, source, and scope using `implementation.owner` and other attributes. Requires `robot.running` and `robot.result` modules. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc1.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.running import Keyword as KeywordData, LibraryKeyword from robot.result import Keyword as KeywordResult def start_library_keyword(data: KeywordData, implementation: LibraryKeyword, result: KeywordResult): library = implementation.owner print(f"Keyword '{implementation.name}' is implemented in library " f"'{library.name}' at '{implementation.source}' on line " f"{implementation.lineno}. The library has {library.scope.name} " f"scope and the current instance is {library.instance}.") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Converting Resource File to and from JSON DESCRIPTION: This Python snippet demonstrates how to convert a Robot Framework resource file to JSON format and recreate it from the JSON data using the `robot.running` library. It utilizes `ResourceFile.to_json` and `ResourceFile.from_json`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/ResourceAndVariableFiles.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.running import ResourceFile # Create resource file based on data on the file system. resource = ResourceFile.from_file_system('example.resource') # Save JSON data to a file. resource.to_json('example.rsrc') # Recreate resource from JSON data. resource = ResourceFile.from_json('example.rsrc') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Output.xml Timestamp Format Update (XML) DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the change in timestamp format within the output.xml file from Robot Framework versions before and after version 7.0. The old format used a custom `YYYYMMDD HH:MM:SS.mmm`, while the new format follows `ISO 8601` standard (`YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.mmmmmm`). SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0.rst#_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` Hello world! Hello world! ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Install Robot Framework using pip DESCRIPTION: This command installs the Robot Framework using pip, the Python package installer. It assumes that Python and pip are already installed on the system. The command downloads and installs the latest version of Robot Framework from PyPI. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/README.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` pip install robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Suite Documentation RobotFramework DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines the documentation for the test suite. It provides a brief description of the purpose of the suite initialization file. The `Documentation` setting allows to add description to the test suite. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/atest/testdata/parsing/data_formats/txt/with_init/__init__.txt#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` Documentation Testing suite init file ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Keyword with Positional-Only Arguments DESCRIPTION: This Python code defines a keyword `keyword` that accepts one positional-only argument (`posonly`) and one normal argument (`normal`). The `/` symbol indicates that `posonly` can only be passed as a positional argument. The function prints the values of both arguments. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_35 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def keyword(posonly, /, normal): print(f"Got positional-only argument {posonly} and normal argument {normal}.") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework with pip DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to install or upgrade Robot Framework to the latest available pre-release version using pip. It uses the `--pre` flag to include pre-release versions and `--upgrade` to update if already installed. Requires pip to be installed. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1a1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: String argument examples - Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Illustrates scenarios where arguments are treated as strings and not converted if one of the accepted types is string. Passing variables of different types allows non-string values to be used. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_56 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Conversion Example 1 big # Argument is a string. Accepted as-is. Example 1 10 # Argument is a string. Accepted as-is. Example 1 ${10} # Argument is an integer. Accepted as-is. Example 1 ${None} # Argument is `None`. Accepted as-is. Example 1 ${1.5} # Argument is a float. Converted to an integer. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Dynamic Type Conversion with Library Instance Access in Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to define a dynamic type conversion function in Python that accesses the library instance to determine the parsing format based on the library's locale. It shows the usage of the `ROBOT_LIBRARY_CONVERTERS` dictionary to register the conversion function. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_67 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from datetime import date import re def parse_date(value, library): # Validate input using regular expression and raise ValueError if not valid. # Use locale based from library state to determine parsing format. if library.locale == 'en_US': match = re.match(r'(?P\d{1,2})/(?P\d{1,2})/(?P\d{4})$', value) format = 'mm/dd/yyyy' else: match = re.match(r'(?P\d{1,2})\.(?P\d{1,2})\.(?P\d{4})$', value) format = 'dd.mm.yyyy' if not match: raise ValueError(f"Expected date in format '{format}', got '{value}'.") return date(int(match.group('year')), int(match.group('month')), int(match.group('day'))) ROBOT_LIBRARY_CONVERTERS = {date: parse_date} def keyword(arg: date): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Running Libdoc with Resource File DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to generate documentation for a resource file using Libdoc. It specifies the path to the resource file and the desired output HTML file. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/SupportingTools/Libdoc.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` libdoc example.resource example.html ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Keywords with Free Keyword Arguments in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use keywords that accept free keyword arguments in Robot Framework test cases. The `Example Keyword` is called with various named arguments, which are then passed to the Python keyword function as a dictionary. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_30 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Keyword Arguments Example Keyword hello=world # Logs 'hello world'. Example Keyword foo=1 bar=42 # Logs 'foo 1' and 'bar 42'. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Multiple EXCEPT Branches in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to use multiple EXCEPT branches to handle different error messages. The EXCEPT branches are evaluated in order, and the first matching branch is executed. It showcases using both literal strings and variables to specify error messages. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc2.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Multiple EXCEPT branches TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT Error message # Try matching this first. Error Handler 1 EXCEPT Another error # Try this if above did not match. Error Handler 2 EXCEPT ${message} # Last match attempt, this time using a variable. Error Handler 3 END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Pushing Changes to Remote DESCRIPTION: This command pushes the local changes to the remote repository, making them available to other collaborators. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/BUILD.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` git push ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accepting Multiple Types in Converter Using Union - Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to allow a custom converter to accept multiple input types using the `Union` type from the `typing` module. The `parse_fi_date` function is updated to accept both strings and integers, where integers are treated as seconds since the Unix epoch. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.rst#_snippet_27 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from datetime import date import re from typing import Union # Accept both strings and integers. def parse_fi_date(value: Union[str, int]): # Integers are converted separately. if isinstance(value, int): return date.fromtimestamp(value) match = re.match(r'(\d{1,2})\.(\d{1,2})\.(\d{4})$', value) if not match: raise ValueError(f"Expected date in format 'dd.mm.yyyy', got '{value}'.") day, month, year = match.groups() return date(int(year), int(month), int(day)) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Specific Robot Framework Version DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to install a specific version of Robot Framework (3.1a1 in this case) using pip. This ensures a consistent environment by specifying the exact version. Requires pip to be installed. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1a1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==3.1a1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Inline Python Evaluation in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework snippet showcases inline Python evaluation. It uses a conditional expression within `${{}}` to determine whether `${x}` is positive or negative, then logs the result to the console. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/Appendices/EvaluatingExpressions.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` Inline Python evaluation Log to console ${{'positive' if ${x} > 0 else 'negative'}} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Advanced External Parser Implementation with Defaults - Python DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates a more advanced external parser implementation that extends the optional Parser base class and handles suite initialization files and default test settings. Dependencies: pathlib.Path, robot.api.TestSuite, robot.api.interfaces.Parser, robot.api.interfaces.TestDefaults. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1rc1.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from pathlib import Path from robot.api import TestSuite from robot.api.interfaces import Parser, TestDefaults class ExampleParser(Parser): extension = ('example', 'another') def parse(self, source: Path, defaults: TestDefaults) -> TestSuite: """Create a suite and set possible defaults from init files to tests.""" suite = TestSuite(TestSuite.name_from_source(source), source=source) for line in source.read_text().splitlines(): test = suite.tests.create(name=line, doc='Example') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Declare Robot Framework Variable DESCRIPTION: This code snippet declares a Robot Framework variable named `${msg}` and assigns it the value 'Running suite setup'. This variable can be used within the test suite. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/atest/testdata/parsing/data_formats/rest/with_init/__init__.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` ** Variables ** ${msg} = Running suite setup ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Checking Python version on Linux DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to check the installed Python version on Linux systems. It shows how to use the `python --version` command and version-specific commands like `python3` and `python3.x`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/INSTALL.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Bash CODE: ``` $ python --version Python 3.10.13 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Inline IF/ELSE Example Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows an inline IF/ELSE statement. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.rst#_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keyword *** Inline IF/ELSE IF $condition Keyword argument ELSE Another Keyword ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Type Hinting with Literal in Python DESCRIPTION: This Python code snippet shows how to use the Literal type hint to restrict the possible values of an argument. The 'arg' argument can only accept the values 'x', 'y', or 'z'. Robot Framework validates the argument value based on the Literal type hint. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0b1.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def example(arg: Literal['x', 'y', 'z']): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: FOR IN ZIP Loop in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework snippet demonstrates a `FOR IN ZIP` loop that iterates over two lists. The loop executes as many times as there are items in the shorter list, effectively ignoring any remaining items in the longer list. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1b1.rst#_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Variables *** @{ANIMALS} dog cat horse cow elephant @{ELIMET} koira kissa *** Test Cases *** Example FOR ${en} ${fi} IN ZIP ${ANIMALS} ${ELIMET} Log ${en} is ${fi} in Finnish END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework VAR Syntax Example DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework code snippet illustrates the usage of the new `VAR` syntax for creating local, suite, and global variables during test execution. It shows how to define variables with different scopes and then validates their values using the `Should Be Equal` keyword. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc2.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example # Create a local variable `${local}` with a value `value`. VAR ${local} value # Create a variable that is available throughout the whole suite. # Supported scopes are GLOBAL, SUITE, TEST, TASK and LOCAL (default). VAR ${suite} value scope=SUITE # Validate created variables. Should Be Equal ${local} value ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Type Hinting with Stringified Generics and Unions DESCRIPTION: This Python code demonstrates the use of stringified type hints for generics and unions, which are compatible with older Python versions. Robot Framework supports argument conversion based on these stringified types. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc3.rst#_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def example(a: 'list[int]', b: 'int | float'): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Test Case with Multiple Date Formats DESCRIPTION: This robotframework snippet shows a test case that uses keywords to handle date in different formats: Finnish (`dd.mm.yyyy`), US (`mm/dd/yyyy`), and ISO 8601 (`yyyy-mm-dd`). It exemplifies the need for custom types and converters to support different input formats. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_63 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Finnish 25.1.2022 US 1/25/2022 ISO 8601 2022-01-22 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using ELSE in TRY/EXCEPT Block in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to use the ELSE block in a TRY/EXCEPT structure. The ELSE block executes only if no error occurs in the TRY block. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** ELSE branch TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT X Log Error 'X' occurred! EXCEPT Y Log Error 'Y' occurred! ELSE Log No error occurred! END Keyword Outside ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Multi-line Value and Separator Usage in Robot Framework VAR DESCRIPTION: Shows how to define scalar variables with long, multi-line values using the `VAR` syntax in Robot Framework. Demonstrates the use of the `separator` option to specify the delimiter for joining the lines. The default separator is a single space character. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0a2.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Long value VAR ${long} ... This value is rather long. ... It has been split to multiple lines. ... Parts will be joined together with a space. Multiline VAR ${multiline} ... First line. ... Second line. ... Last line. ... separator=\n ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing an External Parser with Parser Base Class DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates an external parser class extending the optional `Parser` base class from `robot.api.interfaces`. It includes a `parse` method to create a test suite and sets defaults using the `TestDefaults` object. It also has a `parse_init` method to handle suite initialization files. This illustrates using the base class and utilizing `TestDefaults` for setting test configurations. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from pathlib import Path from robot.api import TestSuite from robot.api.interfaces import Parser, TestDefaults class ExampleParser(Parser): extension = ('example', 'another') def parse(self, source: Path, defaults: TestDefaults) -> TestSuite: """Create a suite and set possible defaults from init files to tests.""" suite = TestSuite(TestSuite.name_from_source(source), source=source) for line in source.read_text().splitlines(): test = suite.tests.create(name=line, doc='Example') test.body.create_keyword(name='Log', args=['Hello!']) defaults.set_to(test) return suite def parse_init(self, source: Path, defaults: TestDefaults) -> TestSuite: ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Documenting Lists and preformatted text DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework example demonstrates how to preserve leading and consecutive internal spaces within documentation and metadata. It shows use cases of creating lists and preformatted text. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/Appendices/DocumentationFormatting.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Long list item [Documentation] ... List: ... - Short item. ... - Second item is pretty long and it is split to ... multiple rows. Leading spaces are preserved. ... - Another short item. Preformatted text [Documentation] ... Example with consecutive internal spaces: ... ... | *** Test Cases *** ... | Example ... | Keyword ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Test Case Example DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework code snippet demonstrates how to use custom type converters with different date formats within test cases. It calls keywords that utilize converters for Finnish ('dd.mm.yyyy'), US ('mm/dd/yyyy'), and ISO 8601 ('yyyy-mm-dd') date formats. It highlights the flexibility of custom type conversion in handling various input formats. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0a1.rst#_snippet_23 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Finnish 25.1.2022 US 1/25/2022 ISO 8601 2022-01-22 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Rebot Tool Merging JSON and XML Files DESCRIPTION: These commands demonstrate how to use the Rebot tool to merge results from both JSON and XML files. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc3.rst#_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` rebot output1.xml output2.json rebot --merge original.xml rerun.json ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Keyword Definition DESCRIPTION: This section defines a keyword named `Failing` that takes an argument `${msg}` and uses the `Fail` keyword to intentionally cause a test to fail. It simulates an error condition. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/atest/testdata/parsing/data_formats/mixed_data/TXT.txt#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` *Keyword Failing [Arguments] ${msg} Fail ${msg} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Recursive Continue-on-Failure DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates the use of the `robot:recursive-continue-on-failure` tag, which propagates the continue-on-failure behavior to called user keywords. All keywords in the test case and any nested user keywords will continue to execute even if they fail. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/TestExecution.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example [Tags] robot:recursive-continue-on-failure Should be Equal 1 2 User Keyword 1 Log This is executed *** Keywords *** User Keyword 1 Should be Equal 3 4 User Keyword 2 Log This is executed *** Keywords *** User Keyword 2 Should be Equal 5 6 Log This is executed ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: List and dictionary expansion example DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the use of list expansion with item access in Robot Framework. It demonstrates how to iterate over a list obtained from a dictionary value using the @{var}[items] syntax. A variable `${var}` with value `{'items': ['a', 'b', 'c']}` is expected to exist. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0a1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` FOR ${item} IN @{var}[items] Log ${item} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Suppress Exception Name - Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to suppress the exception type name from being added as a prefix to the failure message when raising a non-generic exception in Robot Framework. This is achieved by adding a `ROBOT_SUPPRESS_NAME` attribute with value `True` to your exception class. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_74 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` class MyError(RuntimeError): ROBOT_SUPPRESS_NAME = True ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Checking Python version on Windows DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to check the Python version on Windows using the command prompt. It also shows how to use the `py` launcher to select a specific Python version when multiple versions are installed. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/INSTALL.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Batch CODE: ``` C:\>python --version Python 3.10.9 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating custom language files in Robot Framework using Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to create a custom language file for Robot Framework using Python. It involves extending the `robot.api.Language` base class and overriding class attributes such as `test_cases_header`, `tags_setting`, `given_prefixes`, and `true_strings` to define translations. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/TestDataSyntax.rst#_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api import Language class Example(Language): test_cases_header = 'Validations' tags_setting = 'Labels' given_prefixes = ['Assuming'] true_strings = ['OK', '\N{THUMBS UP SIGN}'] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Pipe Separated Format Example - Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the pipe separated format for defining test data in Robot Framework. Each line begins with a pipe character, and data elements are separated by pipes surrounded by spaces. This format can improve readability, especially when arguments contain spaces. It details how to define settings, variables, test cases, and keywords using the pipe separated format. Consecutive spaces or tabs inside arguments do not need to be escaped. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/TestDataSyntax.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` | *** Settings *** | | Documentation | Example using the pipe separated format. | Library | OperatingSystem | *** Variables *** | | ${MESSAGE} | Hello, world! | *** Test Cases *** | | | | My Test | [Documentation] | Example test. | | | Log | ${MESSAGE} | | | My Keyword | ${CURDIR} | | Another Test | Should Be Equal | ${MESSAGE} | Hello, world! | *** Keywords *** | | | | My Keyword | [Arguments] | ${path} | | | Directory Should Exist | ${path} | ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: User keyword with named-only arguments (With Varargs) DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework snippet showcases the usage of named-only arguments in user-defined keywords, including a variable number of positional arguments. `@{varargs}` captures positional arguments into a list, and `${named}` captures the named-only argument. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1b1.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** With Varargs [Arguments] @{varargs} ${named} Log Many @{varargs} ${named} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Multiple Messages in One EXCEPT Branch in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to specify multiple error messages within a single EXCEPT branch. If 'Some Keyword' fails with any of the specified messages, the 'Error handler' will be executed. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc2.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Multiple messages with one EXCEPT TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT Error message Another error ${message} # Match any of these. Error handler END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework ELSE IF Statement DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates using `ELSE IF` in Robot Framework. It checks multiple conditions for the `${rc}` variable. Different keywords are executed depending on whether `${rc}` is positive, negative, zero, or something else. It uses the `$rc` format to avoid evaluation failures if `${rc}` is not a number. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b1.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example IF $rc > 0 Positive keyword ELSE IF $rc < 0 Negative keyword ELSE IF $rc == 0 Zero keyword ELSE Fail Unexpected rc: ${rc} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework 7.2 Beta 1 with pip DESCRIPTION: This command demonstrates how to install the latest available pre-release of Robot Framework using pip. It upgrades an existing installation or installs it if it's not already present. The `--pre` flag is essential to install pre-release versions. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.2b1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Variable Definition in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how scalar and list variables can be defined with the same base name in Robot Framework variable tables. Prior to version 2.9, this was possible but caused confusion. This functionality has been changed in Robot Framework 2.9 to store all variables in the same namespace. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-2.9.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Variables *** ${VAR} Scalar variable @{VAR} List variable ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Install Robot Framework 7.0rc3 (pip) DESCRIPTION: This command installs the specified version of Robot Framework using pip. It ensures that exactly this version is installed. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc3.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==7.0rc3 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Preprocessor Example - Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates an external parser that acts as a preprocessor for Robot Framework data files. It replaces custom headers like `=== Test Cases ===` with standard Robot Framework headers like `*** Test Cases ***` and then uses `TestSuite.from_string` to construct the suite. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1b1.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from pathlib import Path from robot.running import TestDefaults, TestSuite class RobotPreprocessor: extension = '.robot' def parse(self, source: Path, defaults: TestDefaults) -> TestSuite: name = TestSuite.name_from_source(source) data = source.read_text() for header in 'Settings', 'Variables', 'Test Cases', 'Keywords': data = data.replace(f'=== {header} ===', f'*** {header} ***') return TestSuite.from_string(data, defaults=defaults).config(name=name) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework manually DESCRIPTION: This command is used to install Robot Framework manually by extracting the tar file and running the setup script. This is an alternative installation method when pip is not available or preferred. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.0a1.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` python setup.py install ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Specifying language in a Robot Framework data file DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to specify the language for a Robot Framework data file using the `language:` syntax. This enables localization features for the file. Note that this affects subsequent files parsed and is not the recommended way to handle localization. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.1b1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` language: fi *** Asetukset *** Dokumentaatio Example using Finnish. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Specifying language in a Robot Framework data file DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to specify the language to be used within a Robot Framework data file using the `language: ` syntax. This enables localization of keywords and settings within the specific file. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.1b2.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` language: fi *** Asetukset *** Dokumentaatio Example using Finnish. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using @library and @keyword decorators DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to use the `@library` decorator in conjunction with the `@keyword` decorator to explicitly define which methods within a class should be exposed as keywords. Only methods decorated with `@keyword` will be recognized as Robot Framework keywords. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2rc1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from robot.api.deco import library, keyword @library class Example: @keyword def example_keyword(self): # ... def not_exposed_as_keyword(self): # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Run Command with Subprocess (Non-Blocking) DESCRIPTION: This Python snippet demonstrates a more robust keyword to execute a command using `subprocess.Popen` and handles timeouts in a loop. This approach avoids blocking issues but adds complexity to the code. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_107 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import subprocess def run_command(command, *args): process = subprocess.Popen([command, *args], encoding='UTF-8', stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE) while True: try: stdout, stderr = process.communicate(timeout=0.1) except subprocess.TimeoutExpired: continue else: break print(f'stdout: {stdout}\nstderr: {stderr}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Inline IF Statement in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use inline IF statements in Robot Framework to execute a single statement conditionally. Inline IF statements can also include ELSE and ELSE IF branches. If no branch is run when using assignment, the variable gets the value None. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keyword *** Normal IF IF $condition1 Keyword argument END IF $condition2 RETURN END Inline IF IF $condition1 Keyword argument IF $condition2 RETURN ``` LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keyword *** Inline IF/ELSE IF $condition Keyword argument ELSE Another Keyword Inline IF/ELSE IF/ELSE IF $cond1 Keyword 1 ELSE IF $cond2 Keyword 2 ELSE IF $cond3 Keyword 3 ELSE Keyword 4 ``` LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keyword *** Inline IF/ELSE with assignment ${var} = IF $condition Keyword argument ELSE Another Keyword Inline IF/ELSE with assignment having multiple variables ${host} ${port} = IF $production Get Production Config ELSE Get Testing Config ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Type Hinting with Stringified Generics and Unions in Python DESCRIPTION: This Python code snippet shows how to use stringified type hints for generics (list[int]) and unions (int | float). This syntax allows using the type hints in older Python versions (e.g., Python 3.8) where the native syntax might not be available. Robot Framework supports argument conversion using these stringified types. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0b1.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def example(a: 'list[int]', b: 'int | float'): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example Keyword Call (Robot Framework) DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how the example keyword defined in Python is called within a Robot Framework test case. It highlights the change in argument conversion behavior in Robot Framework 6.1, where unrecognized types are skipped and conversion is attempted with the remaining types. The `Example 42` call would pass the integer 42 instead of the string "42". SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1rc1.rst#_snippet_27 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` Example 42 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Handling Errors and No Errors with EXCEPT/ELSE in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to handle both error and no error conditions using an EXCEPT without a message and an ELSE branch. This ensures that either the error is logged or a success message is logged. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc1.rst#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Handle everything TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT AS ${err} Log Error occurred: ${err} ELSE Log No error occurred! END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Removing Global Tags with -tag Syntax DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to remove globally set tags from individual test cases using the `-tag` syntax within the `[Tags]` setting. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc3.rst#_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Test Tags all most *** Test Cases *** T1 No Operation T2 [Tags] one -most No Operation T3 No Operation ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using SHORTEST Mode in FOR IN ZIP Loops DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the `SHORTEST` mode for `FOR IN ZIP` loops, which iterates as many times as the shortest list. Elements in longer lists are ignored. This is the default behavior if no mode is specified. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1rc1.rst#_snippet_22 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Variables *** @{CHARACTERS} a b c d f @{NUMBERS} 1 2 3 *** Test Cases *** SHORTEST mode [Documentation] This loop executes three times. FOR ${c} ${n} IN ZIP ${CHARACTERS} ${NUMBERS} mode=SHORTEST Log ${c}: ${n} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Registering Listener with External Class DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to register an external listener class for a Robot Framework library. The `ROBOT_LIBRARY_LISTENER` attribute is set to an instance of the `Listener` class, enabling it to receive notifications during test execution. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/ListenerInterface.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from listener import Listener class LibraryWithExternalListener: ROBOT_LIBRARY_SCOPE = 'GLOBAL' ROBOT_LIBRARY_LISTENER = Listener() def example_keyword(self): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework with pip DESCRIPTION: These are example commands to install or upgrade Robot Framework to the latest version or to a specific version using pip, the Python package installer. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.1.1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` pip install --upgrade robotframework ``` LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==4.1.1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Test Case using Keyword with Mixed Arguments DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to use a keyword that accepts both embedded and normal arguments in a Robot Framework test case. It demonstrates passing the normal argument both positionally and using keyword syntax. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc3.rst#_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Number of horses should be 2 Number of horses should be count=2 Number of dogs should be 3 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Generating Combined Tag Statistics with Custom Name - Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to generate combined tag statistics and assign a custom name to the combined tag using the `--tagstatcombine` option. The custom name is specified after the pattern, separated by a colon. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/OutputFiles.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` --tagstatcombine "prio1ORprio2:High priority tests" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Custom Date Type Conversion with Class Methods (Python) DESCRIPTION: This Python code defines custom date types (`FiDate`, `UsDate`) that inherit from `datetime.date` and implement custom conversion logic using class methods (`from_string`). These methods parse date strings in specific formats ('dd.mm.yyyy' for `FiDate`, 'mm/dd/yyyy' for `UsDate`). The `@library` decorator registers these converters for use in Robot Framework keywords. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0a1.rst#_snippet_24 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from datetime import date import re from typing import Union from robot.api.deco import keyword, library # Custom type. Extends an existing type but that is not required. class FiDate(date): # Converter function implemented as a classmethod. It could be a normal # function as well, but this way all code is in the same class. @classmethod def from_string(cls, value: str): match = re.match(r'(\d{1,2})\.(\d{1,2})\.(\d{4})$', value) if not match: raise ValueError(f"Expected date in format 'dd.mm.yyyy', got '{value}'.") day, month, year = match.groups() return cls(int(year), int(month), int(day)) # Another custom type. class UsDate(date): @classmethod def from_string(cls, value: str): match = re.match(r'(\d{1,2})/(\d{1,2})/(\d{4})$', value) if not match: raise ValueError(f"Expected date in format 'mm/dd/yyyy', got '{value}'.") month, day, year = match.groups() return cls(int(year), int(month), int(day)) # Register converters using '@library' decorator. @library(converters={FiDate: FiDate.from_string, UsDate: UsDate.from_string}) class Library: # Uses custom converter supporting 'dd.mm.yyyy' format. @keyword def finnish(self, arg: FiDate): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') # Uses custom converter supporting 'mm/dd/yyyy' format. @keyword def us(self, arg: UsDate): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') # Uses IS0-8601 compatible default conversion. @keyword def iso_8601(self, arg: date): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') # Accepts date in different formats. @keyword def any(self, arg: Union[FiDate, UsDate, date]): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Old For Loop Syntax DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates the old FOR loop syntax in Robot Framework, which is still supported in 3.1 for backward compatibility, but is recommended to migrate to the new syntax. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1rc1.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` :FOR ${animal} IN cat dog cow \ Keyword ${animal} \ Another keyword ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Keywords in reStructuredText - Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to define keywords within a reStructuredText document, using both space and pipe-separated formats. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/TestDataSyntax.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` # Both space and pipe separated formats are supported. | *** Keywords *** | | | | My Keyword | [Arguments] | ${path} | | | Directory Should Exist | ${path} | ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Library Listener registration using 'SELF' example DESCRIPTION: This Python code demonstrates how a library can register itself as a listener using the string 'SELF' with the `@library` decorator. This allows the library to receive notifications about events during execution. Requires `robot.api.deco` module. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc1.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api.deco import keyword, library @library(listener='SELF') class Example: def start_suite(self, data, result): ... @keyword def example(self, arg): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Nested FOR and IF Example DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates nested FOR loops and IF/ELSE structures within Robot Framework. It processes cells in rows and executes `Process Cell` only if the cell's value is not 'IGNORE'. This demonstrates how to create complex control flow logic by nesting loops and conditional statements. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0rc2.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` FOR ${row} IN @{rows} FOR ${cell} IN @{row} IF "${cell}" != "IGNORE" Process Cell ${cell} END END END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Pre-run Modifier: Select Every Xth Test - Python DESCRIPTION: This pre-run modifier selects every Xth test case for execution, with customizable starting point. It requires Robot Framework 4.0 or later if using type hints like `x: int`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/ConfiguringExecution.rst#_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` # Specify the modifier as a path. Run every second test. robot --prerunmodifier path/to/SelectEveryXthTest.py:2 tests.robot # Specify the modifier as a name. Run every third test, starting from the second. robot --prerunmodifier SelectEveryXthTest:3:1 tests.robot ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Demonstrating Potential False Positives in ZIP Loops DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows a potential issue where `FOR IN ZIP` loops can lead to false positives if the lists being iterated over have different lengths. The loop will only execute as many times as the shortest list, potentially skipping validation steps. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1rc1.rst#_snippet_20 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Validate something expected 1 expected 2 expected 3 *** Keywords **** Validate something [Arguments] @{expected} @{actual} = Get something FOR ${act} ${exp} IN ZIP ${actual} ${expected} Validate one thing ${act} ${exp} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Install Robot Framework 4.1 with pip DESCRIPTION: Installs the latest available release of Robot Framework using pip. The --pre flag allows installing pre-release versions and the --upgrade flag upgrades an existing installation. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating User Guide Package DESCRIPTION: This command creates the User Guide package by running the `doc/userguide/ug2html.py zip` script. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/BUILD.rst#_snippet_28 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` doc/userguide/ug2html.py zip ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Keyword Should Exist Performance Improvement DESCRIPTION: This enhancement improves the performance of the `Keyword Should Exist` keyword when the specified keyword is not found. This reduces the execution time in scenarios where the keyword existence check fails. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.0.rst#_snippet_7 ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework using pip DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to install the latest pre-release of Robot Framework using the pip package manager. It upgrades the existing installation if one exists. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.0rc2.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Parsing Robot Framework Data with Custom Preprocessor in Python DESCRIPTION: This Python code defines a custom preprocessor for Robot Framework data files. It replaces custom headers (e.g., `=== Test Cases ===`) with the standard Robot Framework headers (e.g., `*** Test Cases ***`) before parsing the data using `TestSuite.from_string`. This enables the use of alternative header formats in Robot Framework data files. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1rc1.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from pathlib import Path from robot.running import TestDefaults, TestSuite class RobotPreprocessor: extension = '.robot' def parse(self, source: Path, defaults: TestDefaults) -> TestSuite: data = source.read_text() for header in 'Settings', 'Variables', 'Test Cases', 'Keywords': data = data.replace(f'=== {header} ===', f'*** {header} ***') suite = TestSuite.from_string(data, defaults=defaults) return suite.config(name=TestSuite.name_from_source(source), source=source) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Create a Test Case in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet showcases how to create a test case in Robot Framework. It includes setting tags, timeout, setup, teardown, documentation, and calling custom keywords with different arguments and formats. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/utest/resources/golden_suite/all_settings.txt#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** My test [tags] sometag someothertag [timeout] 1 minute [setup] Log Test setup msg [teardown] Log Test teardown msg [documentation] Test docs\nwith new line, several spaces " " and a bold tag. My kw This is my _non html_ message\nwith new line, several spaces " " and a bold tag. My kw This is my HTML message\nwith new line, several spaces " " and a bold tag. HTML ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Checking Git Branch DESCRIPTION: This command shows the currently active Git branch. It's crucial to be on the correct branch before starting the release process. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/BUILD.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` git branch ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Specifying language in Robot Framework data file DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to specify the language to use within a Robot Framework data file using the `language:` syntax. This allows for localizing headers and settings. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.0rc1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` language: fi *** Asetukset *** Dokumentaatio Example using Finnish. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Variable Assignment with Multiline Values DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to assign long string values to scalar variables in Robot Framework, splitting the value across multiple lines. It also shows how to change the default separator used to join the lines together. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc3.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Long value VAR ${long} ... This value is rather long. ... It has been split to multiple lines. ... Parts will be joined together with a space. Multiline VAR ${multiline} ... First line. ... Second line. ... Last line. ... separator=\n ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing Library/Resource File via Listener in Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to access information about the executed keyword and the library or resource file it belongs to using the listener API. It accesses and prints information about the library, its scope, instance, source and line number. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/ListenerInterface.rst#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from robot.running import Keyword as KeywordData, LibraryKeyword from robot.result import Keyword as KeywordResult def start_library_keyword(data: KeywordData, implementation: LibraryKeyword, result: KeywordResult): library = implementation.owner print(f"Keyword '{implementation.name}' is implemented in library " f"'{library.name}' at '{implementation.source}' on line " f"{implementation.lineno}. The library has {library.scope.name} " f"scope and the current instance is {library.instance}.") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Inline IF/ELSE with assignment Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows an inline IF/ELSE statement with assignment. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.rst#_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keyword *** Inline IF/ELSE with assignment ${var} = IF $condition Keyword argument ELSE Another Keyword ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Keyword Return Type Specification - Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to specify the keyword return type using the 'return' key in the type dictionary. This information is used for documentation purposes by Libdoc. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_46 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def example2(first, second, third): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Test Case Example DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework test case demonstrates how to use a keyword that accepts date objects in the Finnish date format (dd.mm.yyyy). It relies on a custom argument converter to handle the date conversion. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc1.rst#_snippet_25 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Keyword 11.3.2022 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Basic TRY/EXCEPT Block in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates a basic TRY/EXCEPT block in Robot Framework. If 'Some Keyword' fails with the message 'Error message', the 'Error Handler Keyword' will be executed. Otherwise, the 'EXCEPT' block is skipped. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc2.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** First example TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT Error message Error Handler Keyword END Keyword Outside ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Environment Variables for Robot Framework Options (Bash) DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to set environment variables to specify default options for test execution (ROBOT_OPTIONS) and result post-processing (REBOT_OPTIONS) in a bash environment. The options are defined as a space-separated list and are placed in front of any explicit options on the command line. This is useful for setting global default values. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/BasicUsage.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` export ROBOT_OPTIONS="--outputdir results --tagdoc 'mytag:Example doc with spaces'" robot tests.robot export REBOT_OPTIONS="--reportbackground blue:red:yellow" rebot --name example output.xml ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python 3 Library with Named-Only Arguments DESCRIPTION: Example of using keyword-only arguments (named-only arguments) in a Python 3 based test library. `case_sensitive` must be passed as a named argument. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1rc2.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def sort_words(*words, case_sensitive=False): key = str.lower if case_sensitive else None return sorted(words, key=key) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Listener V3 - start_keyword and end_while DESCRIPTION: Example of a listener version 3 implementation that prints information about started keywords and ended WHILE loops. It demonstrates how to access keyword and control structure data and results, including the line number where they are defined and the status of the WHILE loop. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0b1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.running import Keyword as KeywordData, While as WhileData from robot.result import Keyword as KeywordResult, While as WhileResult def start_keyword(data: KeywordData, result: KeywordResult): print(f"Keyword '{result.full_name}' used on line {data.lineno} started.") def end_while(data: WhileData, result: WhileResult): print(f"WHILE loop on line {data.lineno} ended with status {result.status} " f"after {len(result.body)} iterations.") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing specific Robot Framework version DESCRIPTION: This command installs a specific version (4.0.1b1) of Robot Framework using pip. This is useful for testing or ensuring compatibility with specific environments. It assumes pip is installed and configured correctly. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0.1b1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==4.0.1b1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Rebot Tool JSON Output Example DESCRIPTION: This command demonstrates how to use the Rebot tool to generate a JSON output file from an XML output file. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc3.rst#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` rebot --output output.json output.xml ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Keyword with Flatten Tag (Robot Framework) DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework code snippet demonstrates how to use the `robot:flatten` tag to flatten a keyword during execution. The `Keyword` keyword is tagged with `robot:flatten`, which causes its child keywords to be flattened in the output.xml file. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1a1.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** Keyword [Tags] robot:flatten Log Robot Log Framework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Type Hinting with Union (Old Way) - Python DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates the old way of defining a union type for a function argument in Python, requiring the `Union` type from the `typing` module. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/BUILD.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` git status ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: JSON Variable File Example DESCRIPTION: This JSON file demonstrates the structure of a JSON variable file that can be used in Robot Framework. It defines two variables, STRING and INTEGER, with their corresponding values. IN ENUMERATE` loop syntax in Robot Framework. This loop iterates over a list while also providing an increasing index number for each item. The index starts from 0. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-2.9.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** For in enumerate example # take an item and an increasing index number :FOR ${index} ${item} IN ENUMERATE @{LIST} \ My Keyword ${index} ${item} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Custom Titles for Log and Report Files DESCRIPTION: This command shows how to set custom titles for the log and report files using the `--logtitle` and `--reporttitle` options. This is useful for providing more descriptive names for these files. This allows the library to receive notifications about various events during execution, such as suite start. The `str()` function is used to perform the conversion. The escape character '\' needs to be used. In this example, tests tagged with `require-lxml` are excluded. This is useful when dependencies are not met. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/atest/README.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` atest/run.py --exclude require-lxml ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework 5.1 alpha 1 with pip DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to install the latest preview release of Robot Framework using pip, or a specific version (5.1a1) via pip. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.1a1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==5.1a1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deprecating Tag Syntax in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet highlights the deprecation of using literal values like `-tag` in the `Test Tags` setting to create tags starting with a hyphen. This syntax will be reserved for removing tags in higher-level suite initialization files. Users should use escaped formats like `\-tag` for tags starting with hyphens. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.2b1.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` Robot Framework 7.2 deprecates using a literal value like `-tag` for creating tags starting with a hyphen using the `Test Tags` setting (`#5252`_). In the future this syntax will be used for removing tags set in higher level suite initialization files, similarly as the `-tag` syntax can nowadays be used with the `[Tags]` setting. If tags starting with a hyphen are needed, it is possible to use the escaped format like `\-tag` to create them. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Generating JSON Output File with Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This command demonstrates how to generate a JSON output file during Robot Framework execution. The `--output` option specifies the output file, and the `.json` extension automatically triggers JSON output. The input is a Robot Framework test suite file (e.g., example.robot). SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.2b1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` robot --output output.json example.robot ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Matching Errors with Glob Patterns in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to use glob patterns to match error messages in EXCEPT branches. The 'type=GLOB' parameter is used to specify that the messages should be treated as glob patterns. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc2.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Glob pattern TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT ValueError: * type=GLOB Error Handler 1 EXCEPT [Ee]rror ?? occurred ${pattern} type=glob Error Handler 2 END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Multiple Messages with One EXCEPT in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how a single EXCEPT branch can handle multiple error messages. If `Some Keyword` fails with any of the specified error messages (`Error message`, `Another error`, or the value of `${message}`), the `Error handler` keyword is executed. `${message}` must be defined as a variable. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc1.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Multiple messages with one EXCEPT TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT Error message Another error ${message} # Match any of these. Error handler END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Suite Setup Definition RobotFramework DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines the suite setup using the `Suite Setup` setting. It calls a keyword also named `Suite Setup`, which logs a message stored in the `${msg}` variable. This is executed once before any tests in the suite run. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/atest/testdata/parsing/data_formats/txt/with_init/__init__.txt#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` *Settings Value Suite Setup Suite Setup ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework with pip DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to install or upgrade Robot Framework to the latest version using pip, the Python package installer. It also shows how to install a specific version of Robot Framework. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2.2.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` pip install --upgrade robotframework ``` LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==3.2.2 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Explicit Exact Match of Error Message in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to explicitly specify that an error message should be matched exactly. The `type=literal` parameter (which is the default) ensures that the message is treated as a literal string. This enhancement allows for better control and clarity when defining Robot Framework libraries. Both short and long options are supported. Empty lines and lines starting with '#' are ignored. This file is used to avoid problematic characters on the command line and prevent overly long commands. Error handler END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accepting Multiple Types with Union (Python) DESCRIPTION: This Python code shows how to use `typing.Union` to allow the custom argument converter to accept multiple types, such as strings and integers. In this example, integers are treated as seconds since the Unix epoch and converted to dates. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc1.rst#_snippet_29 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from datetime import date import re from typing import Union # Accept both strings and integers. def parse_fi_date(value: Union[str, int]): # Integers are converted separately. if isinstance(value, int): return date.fromtimestamp(value) match = re.match(r'(\d{1,2})\.(\d{1,2})\.(\d{4})$', value) if not match: raise ValueError(f"Expected date in format 'dd.mm.yyyy', got '{value}'.") day, month, year = match.groups() return date(int(year), int(month), int(day)) ROBOT_LIBRARY_CONVERTERS = {date: parse_fi_date} def keyword(arg: date): print(f'year: {arg.year}, month: {arg.month}, day: {arg.day}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Prior Item Access (Deprecated) DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how item access was previously handled prior to Robot Framework 4.0. This method is now deprecated and it's recommended to use the method described above. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0rc2.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` @{items} = Set Variable ${var}[items] FOR ${item} IN @{items} Log ${item} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Loop Example DESCRIPTION: This snippet showcases the now-unsupported practice of using `Exit For Loop` inside a keyword called from a FOR loop. This is no longer allowed in Robot Framework 5.0. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_23 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** Looping FOR ${x} IN @{stuff} Keyword END Keyword Exit For Loop ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing a specific Robot Framework version with pip DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to install a specific version of Robot Framework using pip. This is useful for testing or using a particular release candidate. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.2rc1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==7.2rc1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Extending the Parser Base Class in Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates a parser class extending the optional Parser base class from robot.api.interfaces. It supports multiple extensions, implements both parse and parse_init methods, and utilizes TestDefaults to set default values for tests. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/ParserInterface.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from pathlib import Path from robot.api import TestSuite from robot.api.interfaces import Parser, TestDefaults class ExampleParser(Parser): extension = ('example', 'another') def parse(self, source: Path, defaults: TestDefaults) -> TestSuite: """Create a suite and set possible defaults from init files to tests.""" suite = TestSuite(TestSuite.name_from_source(source), source=source) for line in source.read_text().splitlines(): test = suite.tests.create(name=line, doc='Example') test.body.create_keyword(name='Log', args=['Hello!']) defaults.set_to(test) return suite def parse_init(self, source: Path, defaults: TestDefaults) -> TestSuite: """Create a dummy suite and set some defaults. This method is called only if there is an initialization file with a supported extension. """ defaults.tags = ('tags', 'from init') defaults.setup = {'name': 'Log', 'args': ['Hello from init!']} return TestSuite(TestSuite.name_from_source(source.parent), doc='Example', source=source, metadata={'Example': 'Value'}) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Inline IF/ELSE IF/ELSE Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Illustrates multiple ELSE IF branches in an inline IF statement. This provides more conditional execution paths within a single inline structure. The example shows chaining multiple ELSE IF statements with a final ELSE. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc1.rst#_snippet_21 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keyword *** Inline IF/ELSE IF/ELSE IF $cond1 Keyword 1 ELSE IF $cond2 Keyword 2 ELSE IF $cond3 Keyword 3 ELSE Keyword 4 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Output.xml Timestamp Format Change DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the change in timestamp format in output.xml from Robot Framework 7.0. The old format used a custom format, while the new format uses ISO 8601 compatible format. Hello world! ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Output XML Timestamp Format Change (New) DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the new ISO 8601 timestamp format in output.xml as of Robot Framework 7.0. Instead of starttime and endtime, the start and elapsed attributes are used. Message times are now stored in the time attribute. Tools that parse output.xml files must be updated to accommodate these changes. Specifically, the syntax `two\n lines` is being deprecated in favor of `two\nlines` because the former was primarily useful for the now-unsupported HTML format. This change aims to simplify string handling and remove obsolete syntax. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2b2.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` Earlier `two\n lines` has been considered equivalent to `two\nlines` in Robot Framework data. This syntax helped constructing multiline strings when using the HTML format, but now that the HTML format is not supported this syntax has been deprecated (`#3333`_). It is unlikely that it would have been used widely. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Output XML Keyword Name Attributes (Old) DESCRIPTION: Shows the old attributes used for storing keyword names and library/resource file names in output.xml files.
