Also this text is outside code blocks and is ignored. Code blocks not containing Robot Framework data are ignored as well. .. code:: robotframework # Both space and pipe separated formats are supported. | *** Keywords *** | | | | My Keyword | [Arguments] | ${path} | | | Directory Should Exist | ${path} | ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Restricting Date Conversion Value Types DESCRIPTION: This Python code demonstrates how to restrict the allowed input types for the `parse_fi_date` function using a type hint (`value: str`). This prevents the converter from being called with unexpected types, such as integers, and results in a clearer error message if the input is not a string. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc2.rst#_snippet_22 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def parse_fi_date(value: str): # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Keyword Structure Flattened with Command Line Option XML DESCRIPTION: This XML snippet demonstrates how the `output.xml` file looks when the `Example` keyword is flattened using the `--flattenkeywords` command-line option. The child keywords are removed, but their messages are preserved, simplifying the structure. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1.rst#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` _*Content flattened.*_ Robot Framework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework with pip DESCRIPTION: This command installs the latest pre-release version of Robot Framework using pip. The `--pre` flag allows installation of pre-release versions, and `--upgrade` ensures that the existing installation is updated. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.2.2.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Generating Combined Tag Statistics - Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to combine statistics from multiple tags using the `--tagstatcombine` option. Combined tags are created using tag patterns with wildcards (`*`, `?`) and logical operators (`AND`, `OR`, `NOT`). SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/OutputFiles.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` --tagstatcombine owner-* --tagstatcombine smokeANDmytag --tagstatcombine smokeNOTowner-janne* ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Variables in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to define list variables in Robot Framework using the `*** Variables ***` section. It shows how to define both English and Finnish lists of animals. These variables are used later in a loop example. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1rc1.rst#_snippet_18 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Variables *** @{ANIMALS} dog cat horse cow elephant @{ELIMET} koira kissa ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Variables Dynamically (Python) DESCRIPTION: Shows how to dynamically create variables in a variable file using Python's standard libraries, providing example of OS variables, random integers, and current time. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/ResourceAndVariableFiles.rst#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import os import random import time USER = os.getlogin() # current login name RANDOM_INT = random.randint(0, 10) # random integer in range [0,10] CURRENT_TIME = time.asctime() # timestamp like 'Thu Apr 6 12:45:21 2006' if time.localtime()[3] > 12: AFTERNOON = True else: AFTERNOON = False ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Variables Section Equivalent to YAML DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows the Robot Framework Variables section that is equivalent to the YAML variable file example. It demonstrates how the YAML variables are represented and used in Robot Framework syntax, creating string, integer, list, and dictionary variables. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/ResourceAndVariableFiles.rst#_snippet_20 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Variables *** ${STRING} Hello, world! ${INTEGER} ${42} @{LIST} one two &{DICT} one=yksi two=kaksi with spaces=kolme ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Updating ByteString Argument Declarations (Python) DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to update argument declarations that previously used `ByteString` to ensure compatibility with Robot Framework 7.0 and Python 3.14. It replaces the deprecated `ByteString` with a union of `bytes` and `bytearray`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc1.rst#_snippet_20 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` arg:ByteString # Old arg:bytes|bytearray # New ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Library Logging During Import with robot.api.logger Python DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to log messages during the library import process using the `robot.api.logger`. These messages are written to the syslog and WARN/ERROR messages are shown in the 'test execution errors' section of the log file. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_89 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api import logger logger.debug("Importing library") def keyword(): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Evaluate Keyword Example in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to use the `Evaluate` keyword to evaluate a Python expression. The result of the expression is assigned to a variable, which is then used in a `Log to console` keyword. This is an alternative to inline evaluation. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/Appendices/EvaluatingExpressions.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` Evaluate keyword ${type} = Evaluate 'positive' if ${x} > 0 else 'negative' Log to console ${x} is ${type} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Escaping Empty Values with Backslash in Pipe Format - Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to escape empty values at the end of a row in Robot Framework's pipe-separated format using a backslash. This is specifically needed when the empty value is the last element in the row. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/TestDataSyntax.rst#_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` | *** Test Cases *** | | | | | Using backslash | Do Something | first arg | \ | | | Do Something | | second arg | ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Suite Metadata DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to set free suite metadata from the command line using the `--metadata` option. Explains how to provide metadata values directly or read them from external files. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/ConfiguringExecution.rst#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` robot --metadata Name:Value tests.robot robot --metadata "Another Name:Another value, now with spaces" tests.robot robot --metadata "Read From File:meta.txt" tests.robot # Value read from meta.txt if it exists. robot --metadata "Path As Value: meta.txt" tests.robot # Value always used as-is. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Embedded Arguments in Library Keywords - Python DESCRIPTION: Shows how to define a library keyword with embedded arguments using the `robot.api.deco.keyword` decorator in Python. The `name` parameter is used to specify the keyword's name with `${args}` placeholders for the arguments. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-2.9.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api.deco import keyword @keyword(name='User "${user}" selects "${item}" from webshop') def select_item(user, item): # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Generating Library Documentation using Invoke DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to generate library documentation using the Invoke task runner. The `` placeholder should be replaced with the name of the library or its unique prefix. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` invoke library-docs ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Mixed Arguments in Library Keywords (Robot) DESCRIPTION: Robot Framework test case demonstrating how to use a library keyword with mixed arguments (embedded and normal). Two different ways of passing the normal arguments are showcased: positional and named. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0a1.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Number of horses should be 2 Number of horses should be count=2 Number of dogs should be 3 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Running Libdoc as a Python Script DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows an alternative way to execute Libdoc by running the `robot.libdoc` module as a script. This method requires specifying the full path to the `libdoc.py` file within the Robot Framework installation. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/SupportingTools/Libdoc.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` python path/to/robot/libdoc.py ExampleLibrary ExampleLibrary.html ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Simple External Parser Implementation - Python DESCRIPTION: This code snippet illustrates a simple implementation of an external parser for Robot Framework. It defines an `EXTENSION` attribute specifying the supported file extension and a `parse` method that creates a dummy TestSuite object. Dependencies: robot.api.TestSuite. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1rc1.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from robot.api import TestSuite EXTENSION = '.example' def parse(source): suite = TestSuite(name='Example', source=source) test = suite.tests.create(name='Test') test.body.create_keyword(name='Log', args=['Hello!']) return suite ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Keyword Example in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how local variables used to leak from test cases to keywords and from keywords to lower-level keywords in Robot Framework. This behavior was unintended and has been fixed in version 2.9, which might break existing tests that rely on this leaking behavior. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-2.9.rst#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Case *** Example ${x}= Set Variable hello My keyword *** Keywords *** My keyword Should be equal ${x} hello ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Keyword Decorator Usage with Library Decorator in Python DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to use the `@keyword` decorator with the `@library` decorator to explicitly expose methods as keywords. Methods without the `@keyword` decorator are not exposed as keywords. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2b2.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from robot.api.deco import library, keyword @library class Example: @keyword def example_keyword(self): # ... def not_exposed_as_keyword(self): # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: VAR syntax for list and dictionary variables DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the usage of the VAR syntax to create list and dictionary variables in Robot Framework. The examples show creating a list with three items and a dictionary with two key-value pairs. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0a1.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** List # Creates a list with three items. VAR @{list} a b c Dictionary # Creates a dict with two items. VAR &{dict} key=value second=item ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Importing ReStructuredText Resource File DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to import a resource file written in reStructuredText format using the `Resource` setting. Robot Framework will parse the file and extract the Robot Framework data from within code blocks. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/ResourceAndVariableFiles.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Resource example.rst ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Problematic Test Case with FOR IN ZIP loop DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework test case illustrates a potential false positive situation when using the FOR IN ZIP loop. The test passes even if `Get something` returns a different number of items than expected, as long as the initial elements match, or even if it returns nothing at all due to the default 'SHORTEST' mode behavior. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1a1.rst#_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Validate something expected 1 expected 2 expected 3 *** Keywords **** Validate something [Arguments] @{expected} @{actual} = Get something FOR ${act} ${exp} IN ZIP ${actual} ${expected} Validate one thing ${act} ${exp} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: New output.xml Timestamp Format DESCRIPTION: Example of the new timestamp format in output.xml, using ISO 8601 compatible YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.mmmmmm format and start/elapsed instead of starttime/endtime. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0b1.rst#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` Hello world! ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Running Libdoc with Python Module Execution DESCRIPTION: This snippet showcases how to execute the `robot.libdoc` module directly using the `python` command. This is useful when managing multiple Python versions and needing to use a specific one with Libdoc. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/SupportingTools/Libdoc.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` python -m robot.libdoc ExampleLibrary ExampleLibrary.html python3.9 -m robot.libdoc ExampleLibrary ExampleLibrary.html ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Basic Robot Framework Library Example (Python) DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows a basic example of a Robot Framework library implemented as a class. It demonstrates how Robot Framework by default excludes methods starting with an underscore from being considered keywords. `my_keyword` will be treated as keyword. `_helper_method` will not. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` class MyLibrary: def my_keyword(self, arg): return self._helper_method(arg) def _helper_method(self, arg): return arg.upper() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Conflicting Embedded Arguments Resolution DESCRIPTION: This robotframework code demonstrates a scenario where a test case matches multiple keyword implementations using embedded arguments. Robot Framework will attempt to find the best match rather than failing. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.1b2.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Automatic conflict resolution Execute "ls" Execute "ls" with "-lh" *** Keywords *** Execute "${cmd}" Log Running command '${cmd}'. Execute "${cmd}" with "${opts}" Log Running command '${cmd}' with options '${opts}'. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework with pip DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to install the latest available release of Robot Framework using pip, including pre-releases. It also shows how to install a specific version. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0.1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Handling Everything with EXCEPT and ELSE in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This shows how to handle cases with errors and without errors in a TRY/EXCEPT/ELSE block. The EXCEPT block catches any error and the ELSE block handles the no error case. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Handle everything TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT AS ${err} Log Error occurred: ${err} ELSE Log No error occurred! END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: RETURN Statement Usage DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates various ways to use the RETURN statement in Robot Framework, including returning values at the end of a keyword, returning conditionally, and returning early. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc2.rst#_snippet_18 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** Return at the end Some Keyword ${result} = Another Keyword RETURN ${result} Return conditionally IF ${condition} RETURN Something ELSE RETURN Something else END Early return IF ${not applicable} RETURN Some Keyword Another Keyword ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Multiline Variable with Separator DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to define a multiline variable in Robot Framework and specifies a newline character as the separator. This results in each line being treated as a separate line in the variable's value. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc1.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` Multiline VAR ${multiline} ... First line. ... Second line. ... Last line. ... separator=\n ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing specific Robot Framework version using pip DESCRIPTION: This command installs a specific version of Robot Framework (3.1.1 in this case) using the pip package manager. This is useful for ensuring compatibility and reproducing results with a known version. It requires pip to be installed. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1.1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==3.1.1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Library Version with __version__ Attribute (Python) DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to set the library version using the `__version__` attribute. This attribute should be a module-level attribute. The `keyword` function serves as a placeholder for actual keyword implementation. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` __version__ = '0.1' def keyword(): pass ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: EXCEPT without messages in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This code shows how to use an EXCEPT branch without any messages to match any error. It can be used alone or after more specific EXCEPT branches. The first example matches any error, and the second matches any error after trying to match a specific error message. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Match any error TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT # Match any error. Error Handler END ``` LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Match any after testing more specific errors TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT Error message # Try matching this first Error Handler 1 EXCEPT # Match any that did not match the above. Error Handler 2 END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Keyword with Implicit Type Conversion DESCRIPTION: This demonstrates how Robot Framework infers argument types from default values when no explicit type is specified. In this case, `count` is inferred as an integer and `case_insensitive` as a boolean. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1rc2.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def example_keyword(count=-1, case_insensitive=True): if case_insensitive: # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Enhanced Listener Methods for Control Structures DESCRIPTION: This enhancement adds more information to the `start/end_keyword` listener methods when they are used with control structures (e.g., loops, conditional blocks). This provides more context to listeners about the execution flow. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.0.rst#_snippet_9 ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Logging with Timestamp - Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to log a message with an accurate timestamp in Robot Framework. The timestamp must be in milliseconds since the Unix epoch and embedded in the message string with the format `*INFO:{timestamp}* Message with timestamp`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_82 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import time def example_keyword(): timestamp = int(time.time() * 1000) print(f'*INFO:{timestamp}* Message with timestamp') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Equivalent --parseinclude usage DESCRIPTION: This example shows how the `--parseinclude` option can be used to achieve the same functionality as the `--extension` option. It is recommended to use `--parseinclude` instead of `--extension` because it's more powerful. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/ConfiguringExecution.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` robot --parseinclude *.rst path/to/tests robot -I *.robot -I *.rst path/to/tests ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Variable Item Access Syntax - Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: In Robot Framework 3.1, syntax like `${var}[xxx]` is now interpreted as variable item access, not a variable `${var}` followed by a literal string `[xxx]`. To treat `[xxx]` as a literal string, it needs to be escaped like `${var}\[xxx]`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1rc1.rst#_snippet_12 ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework with pip (specific version) DESCRIPTION: This command installs a specific version of Robot Framework using pip. It explicitly specifies the version number to install, ensuring that the user gets the exact desired version. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.1.2rc1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==4.1.2rc1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Pre-Run Modifier: Select Every Xth Test - Python DESCRIPTION: This Python code snippet demonstrates a pre-run modifier for Robot Framework that filters test cases, keeping only every Xth test. The modifier takes `every` and `start` arguments to determine the selection interval and the starting index. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/ConfiguringExecution.rst#_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` class SelectEvery: def __init__(self, every: int, start: int = 1): self.every = every self.start = start def visit_test(self, test): if test.parent.tests.index(test) % self.every != self.start - 1: test.parent.tests.remove(test) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Generating Library Documentation DESCRIPTION: This command generates the library documentation using the `invoke library-docs all` task. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/BUILD.rst#_snippet_27 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` invoke library-docs all ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Keyword Definition in Resource File DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines a keyword named 'Keyword in resource.txt' in a Robot Framework resource file. The keyword uses keywords and variables defined in both the current resource file and the nested resource file 'nested.resource'. It uses the 'Should Be Equal' keyword to verify the values of variables. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/atest/testdata/parsing/data_formats/resource_extensions/resource.txt#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** Keyword in resource.txt Keyword in nested.resource Should Be Equal ${NESTED} nested.resource Should Be Equal ${TXT} resource.txt ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Visitor Interface with Listener in Python DESCRIPTION: This example illustrates how to integrate the visitor interface within a Robot Framework listener to modify test suites. It uses a custom visitor (SelectEveryXthTest) to select specific tests within a suite. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/ListenerInterface.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from SelectEveryXthTest import SelectEveryXthTest def start_suite(suite, result): selector = SelectEveryXthTest(x=2) suite.visit(selector) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Checking out a tag DESCRIPTION: This command checks out the specified tag, allowing you to work with the code at that specific release point. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/BUILD.rst#_snippet_21 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` git checkout v$VERSION ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Documenting robot.parsing.suitestructure module with automodule DESCRIPTION: This snippet uses the Sphinx automodule directive to generate documentation for the robot.parsing.suitestructure module. It specifies that all members should be included, undocumented members should be shown, and inheritance information should be displayed. This directive automatically extracts documentation directly from the Python code. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/api/autodoc/robot.parsing.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: reStructuredText CODE: ``` .. automodule:: robot.parsing.suitestructure :members: :undoc-members: :show-inheritance: ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing a specific version of Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This command installs a specific version of Robot Framework using pip. Specifying the exact version ensures that the environment is consistent and avoids unexpected issues due to version incompatibilities. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==4.0b1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: IF/ELSE Structure Example in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework example demonstrates the basic usage of IF/ELSE structures for conditional execution based on an expression. It logs a message to the console depending on whether the variable `${x}` is positive or negative. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/Appendices/EvaluatingExpressions.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** IF/ELSE IF ${x} > 0 Log to console ${x} is positive ELSE Log to console ${x} is negative END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Library Scope Example - Python DESCRIPTION: This Python code demonstrates setting the library scope to 'SUITE' using the `ROBOT_LIBRARY_SCOPE` attribute. This means a new instance of the library will be created for each test suite. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` class ExampleLibrary: ROBOT_LIBRARY_SCOPE = 'SUITE' def __init__(self): self._counter = 0 def count(self): self._counter += 1 print(self._counter) def clear_count(self): self._counter = 0 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Generating JSON output with Rebot DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to use the Rebot tool to convert an existing XML output file to JSON format. This is useful for generating JSON outputs with older versions of Robot Framework or for converting existing XML results. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.2rc1.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` rebot --output output.json output.xml ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Old FOR loop syntax DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the old FOR loop syntax in Robot Framework. Keywords inside the loop must be escaped with a backslash. This syntax is deprecated and users are encouraged to migrate to the new syntax. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` :FOR ${animal} IN cat dog cow \ Keyword ${animal} \ Another keyword ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Executing tests with suite initialization file DESCRIPTION: Example of running Robot Framework tests while using a suite initialization file for the automatically created top-level suite. The init file path is provided similarly to test case files. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/BasicUsage.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` robot __init__.robot my_tests.robot other_tests.robot ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Executing Tests with Batch File DESCRIPTION: This batch file executes Robot Framework tests using different browsers and combines the results using Rebot. It takes arguments and forwards them to the robot command. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/BasicUsage.rst#_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: bat CODE: ``` @echo off robot --name Firefox --variable BROWSER:Firefox --output out\fx.xml --log none --report none %* login robot --name IE --variable BROWSER:IE --log none --output out\ie.xml --report none %* login rebot --name Login --outputdir out --output login.xml out\fx.xml out\ie.xml ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework 7.0 beta 1 specific version DESCRIPTION: Installs a specific version of Robot Framework (7.0b1) using pip. This is useful for ensuring consistency across different environments or for reproducing specific issues. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0b1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==7.0b1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using @not_keyword decorator to exclude functions/methods from Robot Framework keywords DESCRIPTION: The `@not_keyword` decorator is used to explicitly mark a function or method as not being a keyword. It can be useful to prevent certain helper functions from being exposed as keywords in Robot Framework tests. The `not_keyword` decorator must be imported from `robot.api.deco`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api.deco import not_keyword def example_keyword(): # ... @not_keyword def not_exposed_as_keyword(): # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Custom Library Name with AS DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to set a custom name for a library using the AS keyword. This is useful when importing the same library multiple times with different arguments or when the library name is inconvenient. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/UsingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Library packagename.TestLib AS TestLib Library ${LIBRARY} AS MyName ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Catching Any Error in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to use an EXCEPT branch without any messages to catch any error. This branch must be placed after any EXCEPT branches with specific error messages. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0rc2.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Match any error TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT # Match any error. Error Handler END ``` LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Match any after testing more specific errors TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT Error message # Try matching this first Error Handler 1 EXCEPT # Match any that did not match the above. Error Handler 2 END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Re-executing Failed Tests DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use the `--rerunfailed` option to re-execute failed tests from a previous output file. Explains how to combine it with other selection options for fine-tuning. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/ConfiguringExecution.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` robot tests # first execute all tests robot --rerunfailed output.xml tests # then re-execute failing ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Removing Tags with '-tag' syntax DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates removing tags set in the Settings section using the `-tag` syntax in Robot Framework. This allows overriding tags on a per-test basis. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0a1.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Test Tags all most *** Test Cases *** T1 No Operation T2 [Tags] one -most No Operation T3 No Operation ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework List Variable Creation DESCRIPTION: Shows how to create a list variable in Robot Framework using the `@` prefix and assigning multiple values to it. This creates a list with the specified items. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc1.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` List # Creates a list with three items. VAR @{list} a b c ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Keyword with Embedded Arguments DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to define a Python library keyword with embedded arguments using the `@keyword` decorator. The keyword accepts arguments within its name and additional arguments as regular parameters. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc2.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @keyword('Number of ${animals} should be') def example(animals, count): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining a Robot Framework Test Case DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines a test case named 'Suite2 Test' with a specific documentation string. The test is intentionally designed to fail using the 'Fail' keyword. The expected failure message is passed as an argument to the 'Fail' keyword using a variable. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/atest/testdata/parsing/data_formats/rest/with_init/sub_suite2.robot.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` * ********************* Test Cases* *************************************** | Suite2 Test | [Documentation] | FAIL | Expected failure | | | Fail | ${msg} | | | | | | | | | | | | | ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Committing Back to Dev Version DESCRIPTION: This command commits the changes made to the version files, setting them to the next development version. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/BUILD.rst#_snippet_33 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` git commit -m "Back to dev version" src/robot/version.py setup.py ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Plain Text Format Library Documentation Example (Python) DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to document a Robot Framework library using plain text format. `ROBOT_LIBRARY_DOC_FORMAT` is set to 'text'. URLs are automatically converted to links, and internal linking is supported using backticks. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/SupportingTools/Libdoc.rst#_snippet_19 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` """Example library in plain text format. - Formatting is not supported. - URLs like http://example.com are turned to links. - Custom links are not supported. - Linking to `My Keyword` works. """ ROBOT_LIBRARY_DOC_FORMAT = 'text' def my_keyword(): """Nothing more to see here.""" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python: Timeout Handling with explicit Exception Handling DESCRIPTION: This Python code demonstrates how to explicitly catch and handle `TimeoutExceeded` exceptions. It's important to re-raise the exception after handling it to ensure the timeout is properly propagated. Requires `from robot.errors import TimeoutExceeded`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_105 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.errors import TimeoutExceeded def example(): try: do_something() except TimeoutExceeded: do_cleanup() raise ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Resource File Settings Section DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines the Settings section of a Robot Framework resource file. It imports another resource file named 'nested.resource'. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/atest/testdata/parsing/data_formats/resource_extensions/resource.txt#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Resource nested.resource ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Test Data Side Dependencies DESCRIPTION: This command installs the dependencies required for the Robot Framework acceptance tests test data side, conditionally depending on the platform. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/atest/README.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` pip install -r atest/requirements.txt ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Keyword Definition RobotFramework DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines a keyword named `Suite Setup` which logs a message. The `Log` keyword is a built-in Robot Framework keyword that prints the given message to the log file. The keyword is defined using the `*Keywords` section. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/atest/testdata/parsing/data_formats/txt/with_init/__init__.txt#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` *Keywords Action Argument Argument Argument Suite Setup Log ${msg} # No more arguments! ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing Key-Value Tuple in FOR Loop (Robot Framework) DESCRIPTION: Shows how to access key-value pairs as a tuple within a FOR loop when iterating over a dictionary. The tuple contains the key at index 0 and the value at index 1. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2rc2.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` FOR ${item} IN &{dict} Length Should Be ${item} 2 Log Key is '${item}[0]' and value is '${item}[1]'. END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Rebot Tool JSON Output Example DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use the Rebot tool to create a JSON output file from an XML output file. The `--output` option is used with a `.json` extension to specify the output format. The resulting JSON file contains the test results. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` rebot --output output.json output.xml ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework with pip DESCRIPTION: This command uses the pip package installer to upgrade or install a specific version of Robot Framework. It ensures that the user has the correct version of the framework for their project. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0.2.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install --upgrade robotframework ``` LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==4.0.2 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Generating JSON Output with Rebot DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to generate a JSON output file using the Rebot tool with an existing XML output file. This was the way to generate JSON outputs before Robot Framework 7.2. This will convert an existing XML output to JSON. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.2.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` rebot --output output.json output.xml ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Keyword with @keyword Decorator (Dictionary) DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates specifying argument types for a Python keyword using the `@keyword` decorator with a dictionary mapping argument names to types. Works with Python 2 and 3. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1rc2.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @keyword(types={'count': int, 'case_insensitive': bool}) def example_keyword(count, case_insensitive=True): if case_insensitive: # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Running tests with the `robot` command. DESCRIPTION: This command executes Robot Framework tests specified in the `tests.robot` file. The `robot` command is a generic start-up script that automatically selects the appropriate Python interpreter, simplifying test execution across different environments. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.0a1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` robot tests.robot ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Output XML Keyword Name Attributes (New) DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the updated attributes for storing keyword names and library/resource file names in the output.xml. The `library` attribute has been replaced with `owner`, and `sourcename` has been renamed to `source_name` for consistency with the result model. Tools processing output.xml need to adapt to these attribute name changes. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0a1.rst#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` ... ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework with pip DESCRIPTION: This command installs the latest pre-release version of Robot Framework using the pip package manager. The --pre flag allows installation of beta and release candidate versions, and --upgrade ensures any existing Robot Framework installation is updated. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0.1b1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework 5.1 beta 2 with pip DESCRIPTION: These commands demonstrate how to install the latest pre-release version of Robot Framework or specifically the 5.1 beta 2 version using pip. This allows users to test and use the new features. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.1b2.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==5.1b2 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework with pip3 DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to install the latest Robot Framework preview release, or a specific version, using pip3. This is recommended for Python 3 environments. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.0b1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` pip3 install --pre robotframework python3 -m pip install --pre robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Running Libdoc with specific documentation format DESCRIPTION: This snippet generates documentation for a resource file, specifying the output format explicitly as HTML using the `--format` option, and the source documentation format is robot. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/SupportingTools/Libdoc.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` libdoc --format HTML test/resource.robot doc/resource.htm ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Inline IF/ELSE Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the use of ELSE in inline IF statements. These tags override the continue-on-failure setting, causing the test execution to stop at the point of failure. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/TestExecution.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Disable continue-in-failure set using tags [Tags] robot:recursive-continue-on-failure Keyword Keyword # This is executed Disable continue-in-failure in teardown No Operation [Teardown] Keyword Disable continue-in-failure with templates [Tags] robot:stop-on-failure [Template] Should be Equal this fails this is not run *** Keywords *** Keyword [Tags] robot:stop-on-failure ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Generating Acceptance Test Runners DESCRIPTION: This script generates acceptance test runners (files under the `robot` directory) based on the test data files (files under the `testdata` directory). SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/atest/README.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` atest/genrunner.py atest/testdata/path/data.robot [atest/robot/path/runner.robot] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: File Object Access (Deprecated) DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the deprecated method of accessing file objects as lists in Robot Framework. Maximum time is 3.14 seconds. # ExecutionTimeChecker.py must be in the module search path. rebot --prerebotmodifier ExecutionTimeChecker:3.14 output.xml ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Simplified WHILE Loop in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework snippet shows a simplified `WHILE` loop where the loop condition is optional. Error Handler END Match any after testing more specific errors TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT Error message # Try matching this first Error Handler 1 EXCEPT # Match any that did not match the above. Error Handler 2 END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Run Keyword And Continue On Failure Example DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates using the `Run Keyword and Continue on Failure` keyword to ensure that subsequent steps are executed even if a keyword fails. Raising this exception allows the test execution to continue even when a failure occurs. The message provided to the exception constructor is the failure message that will be logged. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_76 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api import ContinuableFailure def example_keyword(): if something_is_wrong(): raise ContinuableFailure('Something is wrong but execution can continue.') ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Boolean True Examples DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates examples of Robot Framework keywords where the 'values' argument is treated as true. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/Appendices/BooleanArguments.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** True examples Should Be Equal ${x} ${y} Custom error values=True # Strings are generally true. Should Be Equal ${x} ${y} Custom error values=yes # Same as the above. Should Be Equal ${x} ${y} Custom error values=${TRUE} # Python `True` is true. Should Be Equal ${x} ${y} Custom error values=${42} # Numbers other than 0 are true. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Generating JSON Output File with Rebot DESCRIPTION: This command shows how to use the Rebot tool to convert an XML output file to JSON. Metadata meta rulez with escaped Metadata version alpha ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Keyword with Default Argument Values DESCRIPTION: This Python code demonstrates how Robot Framework can implicitly determine the type of an argument from its default value. See `introduction` for more information and `My section` to test how linking to custom sections works. """ pass ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Adjusting TestSuite Source for JSON Serialization DESCRIPTION: This code snippet illustrates how to adjust the source path of a Robot Framework TestSuite to be relative before serializing it to JSON, and then adjust it back to an absolute path after deserialization. It utilizes the `TestSuite.adjust_source` method to handle potential path discrepancies when transferring suites between different machines. It depends on `robot.running` for TestSuite functionality. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from robot.running import TestSuite # Create a suite, adjust source and convert to JSON. suite = TestSuite.from_file_system('/path/to/data') suite.adjust_source(relative_to='/path/to') suite.to_json('data.rbt') # Recreate suite elsewhere and adjust source accordingly. suite = TestSuite.from_json('data.rbt') suite.adjust_source(root='/new/path/to') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Serializing a Suite to JSON - Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to serialize a Robot Framework TestSuite object into JSON format using the `to_json` method. It initializes a TestSuite from a file system path and then writes the JSON representation to a file named 'tests.rbt'. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1b1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api import TestSuite suite = TestSuite.from_file_system('path/to/tests') suite.to_json('tests.rbt') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deterministic Library Documentation with SOURCE_DATE_EPOCH DESCRIPTION: This enhancement adds support to generate deterministic library documentation by using the `SOURCE_DATE_EPOCH` environment variable. The command `pip install robotframework==3.0a2` installs Robot Framework version 3.0 alpha 2. These arguments are used to establish a connection. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from example import Connection class MyLibrary: def __init__(self, host, port=80): self.connection = Connection(host, port) def send_message(self, message): self.connection.send(message) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Install Robot Framework using pip DESCRIPTION: Shows how to install the latest pre-release version of Robot Framework using pip, or how to install a specific version. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2b2.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==3.2b2 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Custom Continuable Failure Exception - Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to create a custom exception that allows continuing execution after a failure. This is done by defining a new exception class that inherits from `RuntimeError` and setting the `ROBOT_CONTINUE_ON_FAILURE` attribute to `True`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_77 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` class MyContinuableError(RuntimeError): ROBOT_CONTINUE_ON_FAILURE = True ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Running Tests with Custom Interpreter DESCRIPTION: This command executes all acceptance tests using a custom Python interpreter. It specifies the interpreter using the `--interpreter` option. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/atest/README.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` atest/run.py --interpreter pypy3 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Translation additions and documentation DESCRIPTION: This enhancement focuses on adding and documenting translations within the framework, likely for keywords, messages, and other user-facing elements. It is susceptible to blocking issues, especially on Windows, where timeouts might not work effectively. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_106 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import subprocess def run_command(command, *args): result = subprocess.run([command, *args], encoding='UTF-8') print(f'stdout: {result.stdout}\nstderr: {result.stderr}') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: ValueError Example: Type Hint Restriction Failure DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows the ValueError that occurs when a restricted type is violated. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_18 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` ValueError: Argument 'arg' got value '42' (integer) that cannot be converted to date. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Checking pip version on Windows DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates checking pip version on Windows using `pip --version` and `py -m -m pip --version` SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/INSTALL.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: Batch CODE: ``` C:\> pip --version pip 23.2.1 from ... (python 3.10) C:\> py -m 3.12 -m pip --version pip 23.3.2 from ... (python 3.12) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: FOR IN ZIP loop example with Variables and Test Case DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework example demonstrates the default behavior of the FOR IN ZIP loop when the lists have different lengths. The loop iterates only twice, corresponding to the length of the shorter list, ignoring the remaining elements of the longer list. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1a1.rst#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Variables *** @{ANIMALS} dog cat horse cow elephant @{ELIMET} koira kissa *** Test Cases *** Example FOR ${en} ${fi} IN ZIP ${ANIMALS} ${ELIMET} Log ${en} is ${fi} in Finnish END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example Robot Framework test case using named-only arguments DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework test case demonstrates how to call a Python keyword with named-only arguments. The `case_sensitive` argument is passed by name. Demonstrates usage with and without the named argument. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1b1.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Sort Words Foo bar baZ Sort Words Foo bar baZ case_sensitive=True ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Resource File Variables Section DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines the Variables section of a Robot Framework resource file. It defines a variable `${TXT}` and assigns the value 'resource.txt' to it. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/atest/testdata/parsing/data_formats/resource_extensions/resource.txt#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` *** Variables *** ${TXT} resource.txt ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework with pip DESCRIPTION: This command installs the latest available Robot Framework release using pip. The --pre flag allows installation of pre-release versions, and --upgrade ensures that the existing installation is updated. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0.1rc1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Command Line Search for Deprecated Dictionary Access DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to use the `pss` tool to search for the deprecated dictionary item access syntax `&{var}[item]` in Robot Framework test data files. The `-ai` option performs a case-insensitive search. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2b1.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` pss -ai "&\{.+\}\[" path/to/tests ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework List Expansion with Item Access DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates list expansion with item access. It shows how to access a list within a dictionary and iterate through it using a FOR loop. It requires a variable `${var}` with a value like `{'items': ['a', 'b', 'c']}`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b1.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` FOR ${item} IN @{var}[items] Log ${item} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting GitHub Access Token Variable DESCRIPTION: This command sets the `GITHUB_ACCESS_TOKEN` environment variable, which stores the GitHub access token. It's required to generate release notes from the issue tracker. It allows users to target a particular release for testing purposes. This can be useful for fine-grained control over formatting. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/Appendices/DocumentationFormatting.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Ends with newline [Documentation] Ends with a newline and\n ... automatic newline is not added. Ends with backslash [Documentation] Ends with a backslash and \ ... no newline is added. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Inline IF/ELSE IF/ELSE Example Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows an inline IF/ELSE IF/ELSE statement. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.rst#_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keyword *** Inline IF/ELSE IF/ELSE IF $cond1 Keyword 1 ELSE IF $cond2 Keyword 2 ELSE IF $cond3 Keyword 3 ELSE Keyword 4 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Loop Example DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how loop control keywords (Exit For Loop) can no longer be used directly inside keywords called within a FOR loop in Robot Framework 5.0. It ensures you get the newest version, including alpha releases, which might contain unstable features. Error Handler 2 END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Command Line Tool Search Example DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use the `pss` tool (Python Simple Search) to find old-style for loops (`:FOR`) in Robot Framework test data files. The `-ai` option performs a case-insensitive search, and `path/to/tests` should be replaced with the actual path to the test data directory. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0.1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==7.0.1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing a specific Robot Framework version DESCRIPTION: This command installs a specific version of Robot Framework (7.2.2 in this case) using pip. Specifying the version ensures that the installation is consistent and avoids potential compatibility issues with other software. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.2.2.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==7.2.2 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Execution Side Dependencies DESCRIPTION: This command installs the dependencies required for running the Robot Framework acceptance tests execution side, such as coverage. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/atest/README.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` pip install -r atest/requirements-run.txt ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: JSON Variable File Example DESCRIPTION: This JSON file defines two variables: `STRING` with the value "Hello, world!" and `INTEGER` with the value 42. This file can be used as a variable file in Robot Framework to define variables. The variables can be replaced by their values during test execution. How are you on this @{OCCASION}? ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using @not_keyword Decorator (Python) DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to use the `@not_keyword` decorator to prevent a function or method from being treated as a Robot Framework keyword. This provides a way to explicitly exclude certain functions from the library's keyword list. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2rc2.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api.deco import not_keyword def example_keyword(self): # ... @not_keyword def not_exposed_as_keyword(self): # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Checking pip version on Linux DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to check the pip version on Linux. It shows using `pip --version` and `python -m pip --version` to specify the Python version. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/INSTALL.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: Bash CODE: ``` $ pip --version pip 23.2.1 from ... (python 3.10) $ python3.12 -m pip --version pip 23.3.1 from ... (python 3.12) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Example Keyword with Partial @keyword Type Specification (Dictionary) DESCRIPTION: This Python code demonstrates specifying the type for only one argument using the `@keyword` decorator with a dictionary. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_44 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.api.deco import keyword @keyword(types={'second': float}) def example1(first, second, third): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework 5.0 beta 1 using pip DESCRIPTION: These commands demonstrate how to install the latest pre-release of Robot Framework using pip, or how to install the specific 5.0b1 version. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==5.0b1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Documenting paragraphs DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to create paragraphs in Robot Framework documentation. Lines separated by a single newline are combined into one paragraph, while multiple newlines create separate paragraphs. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/Appendices/DocumentationFormatting.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Documentation ... First paragraph has only one line. ... ... Second paragraph, this time created ... with multiple lines. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Install or Upgrade Robot Framework using pip DESCRIPTION: This command uses pip to install or upgrade Robot Framework to the latest available version. It is the recommended method for installing Robot Framework. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.0.4.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Suite Name DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to override the default suite name using the `--name` option. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/ConfiguringExecution.rst#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` robot --name "Custom name" tests.robot ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Variables with a Dynamic Python Class DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to dynamically generate variables in a Python class using a `get_variables` method. The method accepts arguments and returns a dictionary of variables, enabling dynamic variable creation based on input. This example creates a single variable `${DYNAMIC VARIABLE}`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/ResourceAndVariableFiles.rst#_snippet_18 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` class DynamicExample: def get_variables(self, *args): return {'dynamic variable': ' '.join(args)} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Output XML Timestamp Format - New DESCRIPTION: Shows the new timestamp format introduced in Robot Framework 7.0 for output.xml files. The timestamp is now `ISO 8601` compatible `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.mmmmmm` and is stored in the `time` attribute for messages and `start` and `elapsed` attributes for statuses. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc3.rst#_snippet_19 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` Hello world! ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example keyword with @keyword decorator (Python 2 & 3) DESCRIPTION: This Python code snippet demonstrates using the `@keyword` decorator to specify argument types for Robot Framework keywords. This approach works with both Python 2 and Python 3. Two variants are shown: mapping argument names to types with a dictionary, and mapping arguments to types based on position with a list. In the first case, the `count` argument will be converted to an integer and `case_insensitive` to a boolean. In the second case arguments will be converted to an `int` and `bool` according to their position. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1b1.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @keyword(types={'count': int, 'case_insensitive': bool}) def example_keyword(count, case_insensitive=True): if case_insensitive: # ... @keyword(types=[int, bool]) def example_keyword(count, case_insensitive=True): if case_insensitive: # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Changing Keyword Status via Listener in Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates modifying keyword status within a listener to affect execution flow. It fails keywords that exceed a specified execution time, demonstrating control over keyword results and halting execution. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/ListenerInterface.rst#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from robot import result, running class KeywordPerformanceMonitor: def __init__(self, max_seconds: float = 0.1): self.max_seconds = max_seconds def end_keyword(self, data: running.Keyword, result: result.Keyword): elapsed_seconds = result.elapsed_time.total_seconds() if result.status == 'PASS' and elapsed_seconds > self.max_seconds: result.status = 'FAIL' result.message = 'Keyword execution took too long.' ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Adjusting TestSuite source using adjust_source() - Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to adjust the source information of a Robot Framework TestSuite object using the `adjust_source()` method. This is useful when recreating suites on different machines where the original source paths may not be valid. Dependencies: robot.running.TestSuite. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1rc1.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` from robot.running import TestSuite # Create a suite, adjust source and convert to JSON. suite = TestSuite.from_file_system('/path/to/data') suite.adjust_source(relative_to='/path/to') suite.to_json('data.rbt') # Recreate suite elsewhere and adjust source accordingly. suite = TestSuite.from_json('data.rbt') suite.adjust_source(root='/new/path/to') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework using pip DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to install or upgrade Robot Framework to the latest available pre-release version using pip. It uses the `--pre` flag to allow installation of beta versions. Alternatively, a specific version can be installed. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0.2b1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Run Development Server - npm DESCRIPTION: This command starts the development server using npm. It typically uses Parcel to bundle and serve the application, enabling hot reloading and other development features. The server runs on `localhost:1234`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/src/web/README.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` npm run start ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Multiple EXCEPT branches in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to use multiple EXCEPT branches to handle different error messages. The EXCEPT branches are evaluated in order, and the first matching branch is executed. Variables can be used to specify the error message to match. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0a1.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Multiple EXCEPT branches TRY Some Keyword EXCEPT Error message # Try matching this first. Error Handler 1 EXCEPT Another error # Try this if above did not match. Error Handler 2 EXCEPT ${message} # Last match attempt, this time using a variable. Error Handler 3 END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Union with generics as type hint in Python DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to use Union containing subscribed generics as a type hint in a Python function. This was causing errors in earlier Robot Framework versions and has been fixed in 4.0.2. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0.2.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def example(arg: Union[List[int], Dict[str, int]]): # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Upgrading Robot Framework using pip DESCRIPTION: This command upgrades the installed Robot Framework to the latest stable version using the pip package manager. It requires pip to be installed and connected to the internet to download the latest package. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1.1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` pip install --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Output XML Timestamp Format Change (Old) DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the old timestamp format used in the output.xml file before Robot Framework 7.0. The timestamp, starttime, and endtime attributes used a custom YYYYMMDD HH:MM:SS.mmm format. External tools parsing these attributes need to be updated to handle the new ISO 8601 format. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0a1.rst#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` Hello world! ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Running Libdoc with Library and HTML output DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the basic usage of the `libdoc` command to generate HTML documentation for a library. It specifies the library name and the desired output file name, with the `.html` extension indicating the format. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/SupportingTools/Libdoc.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` libdoc ExampleLibrary ExampleLibrary.html ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Install Robot Framework with pip (Python) DESCRIPTION: This command uses the pip package installer to install the latest pre-release version of Robot Framework. It is the recommended method for installing Robot Framework and ensures that all dependencies are properly managed. The `--pre` flag is required to install alpha or beta versions. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.0a2.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` pip install --pre robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Listing Invoke Tasks DESCRIPTION: This command lists all available tasks defined in the `tasks.py` file, which are used for automating various release-related steps. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/BUILD.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` invoke --list ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Access Modules Examples in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: These examples demonstrate how to access Python modules (os, math, robot) within Robot Framework. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/TestDataSyntax.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.running import TestSuite # Create suite from JSON data in a file. suite = TestSuite.from_json('data.rbt') # Create suite from a JSON string. suite = TestSuite.from_json('{"name": "Suite", "tests": [{"name": "Test"}]}') # Execute suite. Notice that log and report needs to be created separately. suite.run(output='example.xml') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Generating XML Spec File DESCRIPTION: This snippet generates an XML spec file for the OperatingSystem library. XML spec files are designed for tools to programmatically read the library documentation. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc3.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.running import Keyword as KeywordData, While as WhileData from robot.result import Keyword as KeywordResult, While as WhileResult def start_keyword(data: KeywordData, result: KeywordResult): print(f"Keyword '{result.full_name}' used on line {data.lineno} started.") def end_while(data: WhileData, result: WhileResult): print(f"WHILE loop on line {data.lineno} ended with status {result.status} " f"after {len(result.body)} iterations.") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Test Cases Example DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to use a keyword with arguments within a Robot Framework test case.
