IN ZIP ...` loop syntax in Robot Framework. This loop iterates over multiple lists simultaneously, taking elements from each list at each iteration. Both lists must be of the same length or the loop will stop after the shortest list. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-2.9.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** For in zip example # take elements from both lists :FOR ${number} ${name} IN ZIP ${NUMBERS} ${NAMES} \ Number Should Be Named ${number} ${name} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: ByteString argument conversion update (Python) DESCRIPTION: This snippet describes the removal of `ByteString` argument conversion support in Robot Framework due to its deprecation in Python 3.14. Users are advised to replace `arg: ByteString` with `arg: bytes | bytearray` for equivalent functionality. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc3.rst#_snippet_22 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` arg: ByteString -> arg: bytes | bytearray ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Keyword Name Format Change in Output.xml (XML) DESCRIPTION: This snippet showcases changes in how keyword names are stored in the output.xml. The 'library' attribute used to indicate the source of a keyword has been replaced with a generic 'owner' attribute. Additionally, the attribute storing the original name of a keyword with embedded arguments has changed from 'sourcename' to 'source_name'. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.0rc1.rst#_snippet_19 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` ... ... ... ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Old FOR Loop Syntax Example (Deprecated) - Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates the old `:FOR` loop syntax that was deprecated in Robot Framework 3.2 and removed in Robot Framework 4.0. It is provided for historical context to illustrate the syntax that is no longer supported. The example iterates over a list of animals and executes keywords with each animal. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b3.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` :FOR ${animal} IN cat dog cow \ Keyword ${animal} \ Another keyword ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Pushing Tags to Remote DESCRIPTION: This command pushes the created Git tag to the remote repository, making it available to others. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/BUILD.rst#_snippet_20 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` git push --tags ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example Test Case with Teardown Bug DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework test case demonstrates a bug related to `Run Keyword If Test Failed/Passed` and ignored failures. The test is designed to fail in the teardown, but the ignored error is incorrectly considered a test failure. It uses the `Run Keyword And Ignore Error` keyword to suppress an error and subsequently checks if the test failed. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-2.9.1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example No Operation [Teardown] Teardown bug *** Keywords *** Teardown bug Run Keyword And Ignore Error ... Fail This error should be ignored Run Keyword If Test Failed ... Fail Test should have passed ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Specific Version of Robot Framework with pip DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to install a specific version (3.1rc2) of Robot Framework using pip. This is useful for replicating environments or testing with specific versions. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1rc2.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==3.1rc2 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Registering Library Itself as Listener DESCRIPTION: This snippet showcases how a Robot Framework library can act as its own listener. The `ROBOT_LIBRARY_LISTENER` attribute is set to `self` within the constructor. Listener methods are prefixed with an underscore to prevent them from being exposed as keywords. The `ROBOT_LISTENER_API_VERSION` specifies the listener interface version. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/ListenerInterface.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` class LibraryItselfAsListener: ROBOT_LIBRARY_SCOPE = 'SUITE' ROBOT_LISTENER_API_VERSION = 2 def __init__(self): self.ROBOT_LIBRARY_LISTENER = self # Use the '_' prefix to avoid listener method becoming a keyword. def _end_suite(self, name, attrs): print(f"Suite '{name}' ending with status {attrs['id']}.") def example_keyword(self): ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deprecated List/Dictionary Item Access DESCRIPTION: This shows the deprecated syntax for accessing list and dictionary items using `@{list}[item]` and `&{dict}[item]`. The recommended syntax is `${var}[item]` regardless of whether `${var}` is a list or a dictionary. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2.rst#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` @{list}[item] &{dict}[item] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Listing Distribution Files DESCRIPTION: This command lists the files in the `dist` directory, which contains the created distribution packages. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/BUILD.rst#_snippet_23 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` ls -l dist ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: ValueError Example: Invalid Type Conversion DESCRIPTION: This snippet showcases a ValueError raised when an argument of the wrong type (integer) is passed to a converter expecting a string. It illustrates the error message indicating the type mismatch. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` ValueError: Argument 'arg' got value '42' (integer) that cannot be converted to date: TypeError: expected string or bytes-like object ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Library Documentation with Robot Format DESCRIPTION: This example illustrates how to write documentation for a Python library using Robot Framework's own documentation syntax, which supports formatting, links, and more. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/SupportingTools/Libdoc.rst#_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` """Example library in Robot Framework format. - Formatting with *bold* and _italic_. - URLs like http://example.com are turned to links. - Custom links like [http://robotframework.org|Robot Framework] are supported. - Linking to `My Keyword` works. """ def my_keyword(): """Nothing more to see here.""" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Resource File Documentation Example DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to document a Robot Framework resource file and its keywords using the `Documentation` setting. The first line of the keyword documentation is considered the short documentation. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/SupportingTools/Libdoc.rst#_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Documentation Resource file for demo purposes. ... This resource is only used in an example and it doesn't do anything useful. *** Keywords *** My Keyword [Documentation] Does nothing No Operation Your Keyword [Arguments] ${arg} [Documentation] Takes one argument and *does nothing* with it. ... ... Examples: ... | Your Keyword | xxx | ... | Your Keyword | yyy | No Operation ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Parameterized Generics Support (Initial) DESCRIPTION: This enhancement adds initial support for parameterized generics, such as `list[int]`. This allows defining the type of elements within collections, improving type safety and code readability. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.0.rst#_snippet_8 ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Support for non-English Given/When/Then prefixes DESCRIPTION: This enhancement allows the use of Given/When/Then prefixes in languages other than English, enabling tests to be written in different languages. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.0.rst#_snippet_18 ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Old For Loop Syntax Example (Deprecated) DESCRIPTION: This code illustrates the old FOR loop syntax that is deprecated in Robot Framework 3.2 and will be removed in version 3.3. It uses `:FOR` to start the loop and requires escaping all keywords within the loop with a backslash. The loops lack an explicit `END` marker. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2b2.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` :FOR ${animal} IN cat dog cow \ Keyword ${animal} \ Another keyword ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python Library TOC generation DESCRIPTION: This example showcases how to use the %TOC% marker to automatically generate a table of contents in the library documentation, based on the top-level section titles. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/SupportingTools/Libdoc.rst#_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` """Example library demonstrating TOC generation. The %TOC% marker only creates the actual table of contents and possible header or other explanation needs to be added separately like done below. == Table of contents == %TOC% = Section title = The top-level section titles are automatically added to the TOC. = Second section = == Sub section == Sub section titles are not added to the TOC. """ def my_keyword(): """Nothing more to see here.""" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Old FOR Loop Style (Deprecated) DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the old-style FOR loop syntax, which is deprecated in Robot Framework 3.2, especially when using the pipe-separated format. This syntax is no longer supported. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2rc2.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` | :FOR | ${x} | IN | 1 | 2 | | Log | ${x} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deprecated FOR Loop Syntax DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the old FOR loop syntax that is no longer supported in Robot Framework 4.0. The example shows how loops were written prior to Robot Framework 3.1, using the `:FOR` keyword and backslash for continuation. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` :FOR ${animal} IN cat dog cow \ Keyword ${animal} \ Another keyword ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework via pip DESCRIPTION: This command installs or upgrades Robot Framework to the latest version using pip, the Python package installer. It ensures that you have the most recent features and bug fixes. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.1.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` pip install --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Old FOR Loop Syntax Example (Deprecated) DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates the old `:FOR` loop syntax that was supported in Robot Framework versions prior to 3.1 and deprecated in 3.2. It is no longer supported in Robot Framework 4.0. The code shows how to iterate through a list of animals and execute keywords within the loop. This syntax used backslashes for continuation. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0rc1.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` :FOR ${animal} IN cat dog cow \ Keyword ${animal} \ Another keyword ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing List Items Old Syntax DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows the old, deprecated syntax for accessing list items in Robot Framework using `@{var}[item]`. This syntax is variable type-specific and is being replaced by the more general `${var}[item]` syntax, which works for both lists and dictionaries. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2b1.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` @\{list\}[item] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Version in Python Files DESCRIPTION: This command sets the version information in the `src/robot/version.py` and `setup.py` files using the `invoke set-version` task. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/BUILD.rst#_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` invoke set-version $VERSION ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Custom Date Parser Python DESCRIPTION: This Python code defines a function `parse_fi_date` that parses dates in the Finnish `dd.mm.yyyy` format and converts them to `datetime.date` objects. This is used for custom argument conversion in Robot Framework. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0.rst#_snippet_21 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from datetime import date # Converter function. def parse_fi_date(value): day, month, year = value.split('.') return date(int(year), int(month), int(day)) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Iterating Multiple Dictionaries with FOR Loops in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates iterating through multiple dictionaries and adding new key-value pairs within a FOR loop in Robot Framework. The example highlights how the last value is used if the same key appears multiple times. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2rc1.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` FOR ${key} ${value} IN &{first} &{second} one=more Log Key is '${key}' and value is '${value}'. END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Test Library Initialization with Argument DESCRIPTION: This code snippet illustrates how to document the `__init__` method of a test library, which is used to generate the 'Importing' section in the documentation. The documentation and arguments of the `__init__` method are displayed. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/SupportingTools/Libdoc.rst#_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` class TestLibrary: def __init__(self, mode='default') """Creates new TestLibrary. `mode` argument is used to determine mode.""" self.mode = mode def some_keyword(self, arg): """Does something based on given `arg`. What is done depends on the `mode` specified when `importing` the library. """ if self.mode == 'secret': # ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Old-Style FOR Loop Example in Robot Framework (Deprecated) DESCRIPTION: Shows an example of the old-style FOR loop syntax in Robot Framework, which is deprecated in RF 3.2, especially when using the pipe-separated format. This example is not supported anymore. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2.rst#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` | :FOR | ${x} | IN | 1 | 2 | | Log | ${x} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing a Specific Robot Framework Version with pip DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to install a specific version of Robot Framework using pip. Specifying the version ensures that the correct version is installed. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.0.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==6.0 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Specific Robot Framework Version DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates installing a specific version of Robot Framework (6.1.1) using pip. This ensures the project uses a consistent and tested version. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1.1.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==6.1.1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deprecated List/Dictionary Access Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Shows the deprecated syntax for accessing list and dictionary items in Robot Framework using `@{var}[item]` and `&{var}[item]`. This syntax is being replaced by the more generic `${var}[item]` which works regardless of whether `${var}` is a list or dictionary. This example demonstrates the syntax that will trigger deprecation warnings. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.2a1.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` @{list}[item] &{dict}[item] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: IF/ELSE IF Example in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework test case demonstrates the usage of IF, ELSE IF, and ELSE statements. It checks the value of the `${direction}` variable and executes different `Log` keywords based on its value. If none of the conditions are met, the `Fail` keyword is executed. The `${direction}` variable is quoted, or could alternatively be used in the `$direction` format. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example IF "${direction}" == "STRAIGHT" Log Going straight ELSE IF "${direction}" == "LEFT" Log Turning left ELSE IF "${direction}" == "RIGHT" Log Turning right ELSE Fail Unrecognized direction: ${direction} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: List Expansion with Item Access (Old Method) Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates the older, pre-Robot Framework 4.0, method of accessing a list within a dictionary for use in a FOR loop. This method requires first setting the list value into a variable and then looping over that variable, which is less concise than the new method. This method is no longer recommended. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b3.rst#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` @{items} = Set Variable ${var}[items] FOR ${item} IN @{items} Log ${item} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example Robot Framework Task Definition DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework snippet demonstrates the usage of the `*** Tasks ***` header to define tasks instead of test cases, enabling Robotic Process Automation (RPA) mode. This is an alternative to using the `--rpa` command-line option. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1rc2.rst#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Tasks *** Example Log Hello, world! ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Loop Control Keywords Usage (Robot Framework) DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework code snippet demonstrates the (now disallowed) usage of `Exit For Loop` inside a keyword called from a loop. Robot Framework 5.0 and later restrict loop control keywords to be used directly inside `FOR` loops. It is an example of a backwards incompatible change. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0a1.rst#_snippet_25 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Keywords *** Looping FOR ${x} IN @{stuff} Keyword END Keyword Exit For Loop ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework 4.0 beta 3 with pip DESCRIPTION: This command installs the latest available release of Robot Framework using pip. The `--pre` flag allows installing pre-release versions, and `--upgrade` ensures that the existing installation is updated. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0b3.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` pip install --pre --upgrade robotframework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework List Expansion Example DESCRIPTION: This Robot Framework example demonstrates how to iterate over a list obtained from a dictionary using the `@{var}[item]` syntax. It first accesses the list 'items' from the dictionary `${var}`, then iterates and logs each item. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-4.0a3.rst#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` FOR ${item} IN @{var}[items] Log ${item} END ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Boolean False Examples DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates examples of Robot Framework keywords where the 'values' argument is treated as false. Specifically, the strings 'False', 'no', empty string, and Python's `False` are considered false. An example of a special false string specific to a keyword is also included. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/Appendices/BooleanArguments.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` False examples Should Be Equal ${x} ${y} Custom error values=False # String `false` is false. Should Be Equal ${x} ${y} Custom error values=no # Also string `no` is false. Should Be Equal ${x} ${y} Custom error values=${EMPTY} # Empty string is false. Should Be Equal ${x} ${y} Custom error values=${FALSE} # Python `False` is false. Should Be Equal ${x} ${y} Custom error values=no values # Special false string with this keyword. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework from local file with pip DESCRIPTION: This command is used to install Robot Framework from a local tar.gz file using pip. This method is useful when you have downloaded the source distribution and want to install it without an internet connection. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.0a1.rst#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` pip install robotframework-3.0a1.tar.gz ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework 7.1rc2 with pip DESCRIPTION: This command installs the Robot Framework 7.1 release candidate 2 using the pip package manager. It specifies the exact version to install, ensuring consistency across different environments. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-7.1rc2.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` pip install robotframework==7.1rc2 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Python Dependencies with pip DESCRIPTION: This command installs the necessary Python dependencies for release automation using pip, based on the `requirements-dev.txt` file. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/BUILD.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` pip install -r requirements-dev.txt ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Committing Version Changes DESCRIPTION: This command commits the changes to the version files with a descriptive message. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/BUILD.rst#_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` git commit -m "Updated version to $VERSION" src/robot/version.py setup.py ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Test Case Example DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to define test cases in Robot Framework using different date formats. It shows the need for custom type conversion to handle various date formats. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-5.0b1.rst#_snippet_20 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Finnish 25.1.2022 US 1/25/2022 ISO 8601 2022-01-22 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Adjusting Suite Source - Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to adjust the suite source to be relative before converting to JSON and then adjust it back to an absolute path after recreating the suite. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/TestDataSyntax.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from robot.running import TestSuite # Create a suite, adjust source and convert to JSON. suite = TestSuite.from_file_system('/path/to/data') suite.adjust_source(relative_to='/path/to') suite.to_json('data.rbt') # Recreate suite elsewhere and adjust source accordingly. suite = TestSuite.from_json('data.rbt') suite.adjust_source(root='/new/path/to') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Selecting Variables to Include with __all__ (Python) DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use the `__all__` attribute to specify which attributes in a variable file should be treated as variables, providing a way to explicitly define the exported variables. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/CreatingTestData/ResourceAndVariableFiles.rst#_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import math __all__ = ['AREA1', 'AREA2'] def get_area(diameter): radius = diameter / 2.0 area = math.pi * radius * radius return area AREA1 = get_area(1) AREA2 = get_area(2) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Original Keyword Structure Example in XML DESCRIPTION: This XML snippet shows the original structure of a keyword in the output.xml file *before* using the `robot:flatten` tag or the `--flattenkeywords` option. Note the nested `kw` elements representing the individual `Log` calls within the `Example` keyword. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1rc1.rst#_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` Robot Logs the given message with the given level. Robot Framework Logs the given message with the given level. Framework ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: TestSuite Defaults Initialization Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to create a dummy test suite and set default tags, setup, and metadata using the `TestSuite` class in Robot Framework. It's typically used when parsing initialization files with supported extensions. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-6.1.rst#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` defaults.tags = ('tags', 'from init') defaults.setup = {'name': 'Log', 'args': ['Hello from init!']} return TestSuite(TestSuite.name_from_source(source.parent), doc='Example', source=source, metadata={'Example': 'Value'}) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Pattern Matching with Square Brackets - Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: Robot Framework 3.1 introduces support for using `[chars]` as a pattern matching any character inside the brackets in glob-like patterns. This change affects existing patterns that use square brackets as literal characters, requiring them to be escaped or replaced with a question mark (`?`). Additionally, a bug related to trailing newlines in matched strings has been fixed, making pattern matching more strict. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1rc1.rst#_snippet_11 ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Console Output Control Examples DESCRIPTION: Examples of using console output control options. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/ConfiguringExecution.rst#_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: RobotFramework CODE: ``` robot --console quiet tests.robot robot --dotted tests.robot ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example test case using automatic argument conversion DESCRIPTION: This robotframework snippet shows how to define test cases which use the automatic argument conversion feature of Robot Framework 3.1. The values 42 and False will be automatically converted to an integer and a boolean respectively before being passed to `Example Keyword`. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.1b1.rst#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Test Cases *** Example Example Keyword 42 False ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Python: Timeout Handling with try/finally DESCRIPTION: This Python code demonstrates how to use `try/finally` to ensure cleanup activities are always executed, even if a `TimeoutExceeded` exception occurs during keyword execution. The `do_cleanup` function will always be called. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExtendingRobotFramework/CreatingTestLibraries.rst#_snippet_104 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` def example(): try: do_something() finally: do_cleanup() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Robot Framework from Source DESCRIPTION: These commands describe how to install Robot Framework from a source distribution downloaded from PyPI. It involves extracting the archive and running the setup script with Python. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/releasenotes/rf-3.0.rst#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` python setup.py install ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using JSON Output with Rebot DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use JSON output files as input to Rebot for creating reports and logs. Also shows examples of combining and merging XML and JSON output files. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/doc/userguide/src/ExecutingTestCases/PostProcessing.rst#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` rebot output.json rebot output1.json output2.json rebot output1.xml output2.json rebot --merge original.xml rerun.json ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Robot Framework Settings Definition DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines settings for a Robot Framework test suite. It includes documentation for the root suite, metadata, a suite setup that logs 'Rock on', and a suite teardown that fails. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/utest/resources/golden_suite/__init__.txt#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Robot Framework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** documentation root docs \nwith new line, several spaces " \ \ \ " and a bold tag. metadata root rocks suite setup Log Rock on Suite teardown Fail ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Settings and Variables in Robot Framework DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines Robot Framework settings including Resource and Invalid Resource, along with a variable named rest_resource_var. The Resource setting imports 'rest_directive_resource2.rest' and 'Setting' for Invalid Resource. The variable is assigned the value 'ReST Resource Variable'. SOURCE: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/atest/testdata/parsing/data_formats/resources/rest_directive_resource.rst#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: robotframework CODE: ``` *** Settings *** Resource rest_directive_resource2.rest Invalid Resource Setting *** Variables *** ${rest_resource_var} ReST Resource Variable ```
